In situations where close contact cannot be avoided, close contacts of the person under quarantine do not also need to quarantine. For example, if someone under quarantine depends on another person for care and basic needs, and close contact cannot be avoided, the caregiver may continue with activities outside of the home. For example, the caregiver may continue to go to work, school, child care, the grocery store, etc.
As much as possible, continue to practice these prevention steps. Stay at least 6 feet from the person who is under quarantine. People who are under quarantine should wear a mask in common spaces, use a separate bathroom, eat separately, and otherwise not be in close contact with others in the household who are not under quarantine. Be sure to disinfect commonly touched surfaces, and check yourself for symptoms for 14 days.
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others to prevent further spread. Quarantine means staying at a home or dwelling for 14 days since the day they were potentially exposed, before doing any activities outside of the home. People in quarantine should separate themselves from others and check themselves for symptoms.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How is a sample collected for COVID-19 testing?
answerText:
Usually, samples (specimens) are collected from you in one of two ways:

Nasal swab - this is a short, dry swab that is used to collect a sample from the front of your nose. This type of test is used at the Health Departmentâs testing sites. It is also used for certain priority groups, including children.
Nasopharyngeal or NP swab â this is a long, dry swab that is inserted through one nostril and is rubbed against the back of your nose and throat.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What information is available for long-term care facilities and other facilities that serve older Vermonters (group homes, nursing homes, assisted living, and state therapeutic care residences)?
answerText:
Facilities may offer visitation with residents. Check with the facility first before planning a visit. Medically necessary personnel and visitors for residents receiving end-of-life care are allowed inside. Read the executive order.
Long-term care facilities are following guidance from the Department of Aging and Independent Living (DAIL). Check with the long-term care facility to find out what restrictions are in place.
There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.
The Health Department recommends surveillance testing at long-term care facilities to identify people with COVID-19 and to help stop outbreaks in long-term care facilities.
The Health Department recommends that all health care personnel in long-term care facilities and other congregate care settings where health care is provided wear face masks, regardless of the presence of COVID-19 in the facility.
COVID-19 activity in the community may affect how facilities and providers make decisions about testing, operations and personal protective equipment (PPE). Find information for health care providers, nursing homes and other long-term care facilities to make decisions based on measures of community-level burden.
Residents and staff of congregate care settings and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period. Testing out of quarantine after day 7 is not an option unless alternate guidance is provided by the Health Department.
See the reopening guidance from DAIL regarding senior centers and adult day centers.
There is guidance Â­on preventing the spread of COVID-19 for managers and owners of senior living communities, which includes making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents/staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.
Find more guidance and information for long-term care and group living settings.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is Sara Alert?
answerText:
Sara Alert is a free, automated and secure reminder system to check for common symptoms of COVID-19. Sara Alert is for:

People who test positive for COVID-19
Close contacts of people with COVID-19
People visiting or returning to Vermont

Once you sign up, Sara Alert sends daily reminders until they automatically stop after two weeks. You can choose to receive messages by email, text or phone. If you report symptoms, the Health Department will reach out to provide guidance and next steps.
Sara Alert is not a contact tracing system. It is not GPS-based, so it does not monitor your movements or track your location.
Here are some reasons why you should sign up for Sara Alert:

You get fast, easy, and free reminders to check yourself for symptoms.
You get quick access to the Health Department for guidance and information if you develop symptoms.
It helps our public health teams contain the spread of COVID-19.

If you are a close contact of someone who has COVID-19, you will be given the link to sign up for Sara Alert when you are notified.
If you are visiting Vermont or recently returned to Vermont, learn more about Sara Alert and sign up. Visitors or returning travelers who are currently enrolled in Sara Alert who have questions about their messages can email the Travel Team or call 802-863-7240 (option 6).
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What should communities of faith do?
answerText:
For many traditions, gathering together is the heart of a faith-based community. Gatherings can increase the risk of spreading COVID-19, so it's important to follow public health guidelines to keep communities safeÂ while keeping traditions alive.
Religious facilities and places of worship can operate under certain health and safety requirements from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD). Find out what actions congregates, attendees, and organizations leaders and staff can take to stay safe.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How can I stay up to date on the latest COVID-19 guidance and information?
answerText:
The most current comprehensive guidance and information is on the Health Departmentâs COVID-19 website and the Agency of Commerce and Community Developmentâs (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Recovery Center. You canÂ sign up for the Health Departmentâs Weekly COVID-19 E-Newsletter to get the latest news.
You can also sign up to get notifications from VT-ALERT. VT-ALERT sends important updates to the Governorâs Executive Orders and other related COVID-19 announcements that will directly impact Vermonters. You can get notifications by email, text, phone and the Everbridge mobile app. You can also specify geographic areas (for example, the town or county where you live or work). Once you register for VT-ALERT, select the alerts you would like to get. COVID-19 information is listed under âHealth Alertsâ. If you are already subscribed, you can update your subscriptions after you log in.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do I do if I believe I had close contact with someone who has COVID-19?
answerText:
When someone tests positive for COVID-19, the Health Department works with them to identify their close contacts. Generally, these are people you were within 6 feet of, for a total of 15 minutes or more over a 24-hour period, during the time they were infectious (contagious).
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a textÂ message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone whoÂ tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from aÂ Health Department Contact Tracer.Â Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
If you are not identified as a close contact, then you will not be called. While contact tracers work to identify all close contacts, all might not be identified. If you think that you might be a close contact but didn't get a call, you may take precautions by quarantining for 14 days since the last day you were in contact with that person, and get tested on day 7 or after if you have not had any symptoms.
If you are not a close contact of a person who tested positive, you can continue to follow the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is contact tracing?
answerText:
Contact tracing is used to provide education, support and guidance to people who are diagnosed with an infectious disease. Itâs also used to identify people who have been in close contact with them, so they can take steps to stop the disease from spreading to others.
If you test positive for COVID-19, you will get a call from the Health Department. A trained public health worker, called a contact tracer, will give you guidance to stay home and away from other people until you recover. This stops the virus from spreading to other people. They will ask you questions about your symptoms, activities, and who you may have come into contact with during a specific period of time. This information is only used to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will contact you and tell you the date when you may have been exposed. They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time. They will ask you to watch for symptoms and ask if you need any help while staying home.
If you receive a text message from 89361, this is a notification from the Health Department that you are a close contact of someone who tested positive for COVID-19. Soon you will receive a call from a Health Department Contact Tracer. Find out what you need to do if you are a close contact.
Itâs important to answer the call and to answer questions as completely as possible to make sure everyone knows what steps to take to prevent further spread of the virus. Governor Scottâs Executive Order calls on Vermonters to comply with all contact tracing requests.
All restaurants and other businesses are keeping a 30-day log of employee and guest names and contact information in case contact tracing is needed.
Consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of COVID-19.
Currently, Vermont is not participating in the contact tracing notifications that are available on some cell phones. We are waiting to see how successful this service is in other states who are participating. If itâs proven to be effective, we will consider using it.
Learn how contact tracing for COVID-19 works in Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Are there any recommendations for older adults (65 years and older) and people of any age with underlying medical conditions?
answerText:
According to the CDC, the risk for severe illness from COVID-19 increases with age, with older adults at highest risk, and is higher for people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. Severe illness means that the person with COVID-19 may require hospitalization, intensive care, or a ventilator to help them breathe, or they may even die.
If you are in one of these groups, take these extra precautions in addition to the COVID-19 prevention steps:

Stay close to home as much as possible. Traveling out of state is not recommended since the virus is still widespread in neighboring states and across the country.
Be aware of your surroundings. Choose outdoor settings over indoor settings. Pay attention to the size of the space, crowding, the number of people there, and if they are wearing face coverings and keeping a 6-foot distance.
Choose activities that donât require close contact. Minimize close contact while talking or doing anything that requires exertion, shouting or singing.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with

The CDC recommends other populations also take extra precautions, like pregnant people, people experiencing homelessness, and people with disabilities.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Why are rates used on the town map, and how are they calculated?
answerText:
The rate of recent cases by town map reflects the rate of cases of COVID-19 among Vermont residents per 10,000 people, by town of residence, from the past two weeks. Rates are commonly used because they allow us to compare the number of cases across towns that have different population sizes.
To calculate the rate by town in the last two weeks, we take the number of cases reported in the last two weeks in a town and divide it by that townâs population. That number is multiplied by 10,000 people. This is the rate, or number of cases per 10,000 people.
Use the map to compare how prevalent COVID-19 is in a town over the past two weeks, relative to other towns. The map may help communities assess how their town is doing and take additional actions to prevent the spread of COVID-19 when necessary.
When looking at the town rates, please remember that having a lower rate of recent cases is not the same as âsafer.â We know the virus is in our communities, and we should continue to follow health guidance to slow the spread of COVID-19 â no matter where we live or where we visit. The data reflect the rate of people who had a positive test. There may be people in your town that have COVID-19 but have not been tested.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is Vermont doing?
answerText:
Governor Phil Scott declared a State of Emergency to respond to the COVID-19 pandemicÂ to help ensure Vermont has all the necessary resources to respond to this evolving public health emergency. Find details on all executive orders.
The strategies continue to be updated based on guidance from federal and state public health officials. Find a summary of current strategies on the Governor's website.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How are the Governorâs executive orders being enforced?
answerText:
Enforcement of the Governorâs executive orders â Be Smart, Stay Safe â is mainly done through education and voluntary compliance. Law enforcement officers are encouraged to talk to people or businesses if they see or are made aware of possible violations.

The orders do not close roads, do not establish roadblocks or checkpoints, and do not require people to show their identification.
People may be out and about. Motor vehicles with Vermont and out-of-state registrations are allowed to operate.
There will be no motor vehicle stops and no people detained for questioning about their travel.

If you have a concern about businesses, lodging establishments, short-term rental properties, nonprofits, other entitiesÂ that are violating the Governorâs orders or people who are not quarantining as required, call your local law enforcement agency or file a report online.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Are face masks or coverings required in Vermont?
answerText:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Face masks or coverings are not required when you are doing strenuous exercise or activities. They are also not required for â and should not be worn by:

Children under the age of 2
Anyone who has trouble breathing
Anyone who is unable to remove the face mask without assistance
Anyone who has a medical or behavioral reason for not wearing a face mask

If you have a medical or developmental condition or have trouble breathing, you are not required to show evidence or documentation of your condition.
Businesses and other entities may also post signage explaining their mask requirements and can deny entry or service to people who are not wearing a mask, including people who are not required to wear a mask. However, the business must provide another way for people who are unable to wear a mask to access the business (for example, offering curbside pick-up or delivery or other creative solution).
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a face mask or covering anytime youâre around people you donât live with.
Wearing face masks or coverings helps keep people from spreading the virus. This is because the virus can spread even if a person does not have any symptoms.
In addition to wearing face masks or coverings, these are things you can do to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.

Learn more about why, how and when to do these things.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.why, how and when to do these things
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How do I wash or sanitize my hands to keep from getting sick?
answerText:
The CDC recommends washing your hands often with soap and water for 20 seconds. To prevent the spread of germs during the COVID-19 pandemic, itâs especially important to wash your hands before and after:

Touching your eyes, nose or mouth
Eating or preparing food
Blowing your nose, coughing or sneezing
Touching your mask
Entering and leaving a public place
Touching an item or surface that may be frequently touched by other people (such as door handles, tables, gas pumps, shopping carts, or electronic cashier registers/screens, etc.)
Caring for someone who is sick

If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Cover all surfaces of your hands and rub them together until they feel dry. Always wash your hands with soap and water if they look dirty.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is the correct way to wear a face mask or covering?
answerText:
You are required to wear a face mask or covering in public spaces in Vermont. This includes both indoor and outdoor public spaces (for example, businesses, public buildings, parks), group living settings (for example, long-term care facilities, nursing homes, apartment and condo complexes), and other places where itâs not possible to stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you wear a mask anytime you're around people you donât live with.
People with COVID-19 can spread the virus even if they donât have any symptoms. Masks protect others around you as well as offer some protection to you.
A mask must be worn properly to be effective and avoid spreading the virus:

Wash your hands or use hand sanitizer before putting it on.
Put it over your nose and mouth and secure it under your chin.
Make sure it fits snugly against the side of your face.
Slip the loops over your ears or tie the strings behind your head.
Do not touch it when you are wearing it.
Remove it by handling only the ear loops or ties and fold the outside corners together.
Be careful not to touch your eyes, nose or mouth, then wash your hands immediately after removing it.

Wash your mask regularly and make sure itâs completely dry before using it again. Have a few on hand so you can rotate them for washing and have enough clean ones to wear.
During hot weather, if you feel like you are overheating and are having trouble breathing because it is hot, take off your mask, drink water, rest and seek shade or a cool place. It is important that you stay at least 6 feet away from others whenever possible, especially when you are not wearing a mask.
During cold weather, change your mask when it becomes wet. Keep a spare mask to replace the wet one, and put the wet one in a plastic bag until you get home. If you need to wear a scarf, ski mask or balaclava, wear it over your mask. If you wear glasses, find a mask that fits closely over your nose or has a nose wire to help reduce fogging.
Wearing masks is one way we can help slow the spread of COVID-19 â in addition to staying at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and other prevention steps.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
How to select, clean and wear your face mask

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth face masks to the public. Find out if free cloth face masks are available in your area.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I get together with friends and family?
answerText:
As of November 14, 2020, you are not allowed to gather with people you donât live with. This includes all inside and outside social and entertainment gatherings, and in public and private spaces. Learn more about what this means.
If you do gather with people you donât live with, you should quarantine. Quarantine means staying home and away from other people for 14 days. The Health Department strongly encourages you to get tested as soon as possible after the gathering and then again on day 7. If you have not had symptoms of COVID-19, you have the option to get a PCR test on day 7 and end your quarantine with a negative test result.
If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.
Follow these general prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you don't live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Also, consider keeping a contact journal â a list of other people who you have been in close contact with each day. If you do get sick, this would make it easier to get in touch with those people and so they can take proper precautions to prevent further spread of the virus.
The risk for severe illness increases with age and is higher for older adults and people of any age with certain underlying medical conditions. They should consider taking additional steps to limit their risk, stay close to home, and family and friends should do everything they can to help keep them safe.
Learn more from the CDC:

Hosting gatherings or cook-outs
Attending an event or gathering
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What protections are in place for congregate care settings and long-term care facilities?
answerText:
The Health Department has contacted all long-term care facilities, nursing homes, assisted living facilities, and senior housing facilities proactively to review strategies to prevent COVID-19 infection and develop plans to respond immediately if an infection is identified. We complete an in-depth assessment by phone and provide guidance about personal protective equipment and other infection prevention and control recommendations. We continue to stay in touch for any technical assistance needs and additional questions.
If a case of COVID-19 is associated with a long-term care facility, an epidemiology team is quickly activated. They contact the facility to provide recommendations and infection control support. The team begins contact tracing to determine the source of the infection and how it may be spreading. They ask questions and collect information to help identify anyone the patient had close contact with. (Close contact means being closer than 6 feet apart for a long time while the person was infectious.) The team communicates with close contacts to ensure isolation and quarantine guidelines are being followed, which will differ depending on the type of setting.
Vermont is taking measures to slow the spread of COVID-19 in certain types of group living facilities, including nursing homes, assisted living facilities, residential care homes, therapeutic community residences, residential treatment centers, correctional facilities,Â state psychiatric care facilities, and homeless shelters.
If a staff member or resident tests positive for COVID-19, facility-wide testing of staff and residents might be recommended in consultation with the Health Department. If facility-wide testing is recommended, the Health Department provides technical assistance to make sure that the facility is connected with testing resources and provides guidance on when additional rounds of testing should take place. The Health Department also works closely with the facility to provide infection control guidance and resources.
Additionally, many long-term care facilities are conducting ongoing staff surveillance testing. For related guidance, read the Long Term Care Guidance for Operations During COVID-19 Health Emergency from the Department of Disabilities, Aging and Independent Living (DAIL) and Testing Recommendations for Long-term Care Facilities from the Health Department.
There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities, which is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays.
Residents and staff of group living facilities and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine period first.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is a âprobable caseâ?
answerText:
A case is considered âprobableâ if the person:

tested positive on an antigen test and has symptoms of COVID-19 or epidemiologic evidence, or
has symptoms of COVID-19 and is epidemiologically linked to a confirmed case of COVID-19.

As of December 2, probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 cases in Vermont.
As of January 4, deaths among probable cases are included in the number of COVID-19 deaths in Vermont. A death among a probable case is a person who:

meets the probable case definition and has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate or
has COVID-19 listed as a cause or contributing condition on their death certificate.

The Health Department follows the nationally recognized definition of COVID-19 cases, developed by the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE) in April 2020. Since then, the Health Department has tracked probable cases and taken the same public health actions as if they were a confirmed case (confirmed means the person tested positive on a PCR test).
This means that contact tracers conduct interviews with people who are considered probable cases, provide isolation guidance, and their close contacts are notified to quarantine. People who are considered probable cases are also encouraged to get a follow-up PCR test. If they test positive on a follow-up PCR test, they are only included once in the total case count.
The Health Department began including probable cases and deaths in counts to more accurately represent COVID-19 activity and because antigen testing in Vermont is increasing. Right now, this change does not impact hospitalization or testing data.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I take care of someone who is in isolation because they tested positive for COVID-19, but I canât avoid close contact with them. Do I need to quarantine?
answerText:
Yes. In situations where you cannot avoid close contact with someone with COVID-19, you should quarantine while the person you are caring for is sick. You should also quarantine for 14 days after they are able to end home isolation.
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from other people. Quarantine means you need to stay home and away from other people for 14 days since the day you were potentially exposed. You should separate yourself from others and check yourself for symptoms. Learn about the option to be tested to end quarantine after 7 days.
Find tips on what to do when a household member is sick with COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What should pregnant or breastfeeding people do?
answerText:
Based on what we know at this time,Â pregnant peopleÂ are at an increased risk for severe illness from COVID-19 and death,Â compared to non-pregnant people. Additionally, pregnant people with COVID-19 might be at increased risk of other adverse outcomes, such as preterm birth (delivering the baby earlier than 37 weeks). Therefore,Â it is especially important for pregnant people, and those who live with them, to protect themselves from getting COVID-19.
We donât know for sure if people with COVID-19 can spread the virus to babies through their breast milk, but the current evidence suggests that this isnât likely.
Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 and pregnancy and breastfeeding.
Find more resources for families with children.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How can I help protect myself from getting the virus?
answerText:
The virus is thought to spread mainly through close contact from person to person. Here is how you can protect yourself from getting COVID-19 and from spreading it to others:

Stay home and away from others if you are sick.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol, especially after being in a public place, before eating, and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
Keep your social circle small. At this time, your social circle should only include the people you live with. If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors.
Stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with.
Wear a mask anytime you are around people you donât live with.
Have the âCOVID Talkâ with people before you make plans and share what you need to feel safe and comfortable.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Avoid crowded indoor spaces.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue or the inside of your elbow. Throw the tissue in the trash and wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily.
Limit your travel. Check Vermont's travel guidance, and read CDC's guidance on travel in the United States.

Learn more:

Preventing COVID-19
Daily activities and going out
How to help care for someone sick at home
How to protect yourself and others
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What are the symptoms of COVID-19?
answerText:
People with COVID-19 have had a wide range of symptoms reported â ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. Symptoms may start 2 to 14 days after exposure to the virus. People with these symptoms may have COVID-19:

Fever (100.4Â°F or greater)
Cough
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Chills
Fatigue
Muscle or body aches
Headache
New loss of taste or smell
Sore throat
Congestion or runny nose
Nausea or vomiting
Diarrhea

This list does not include all possible symptoms. The CDC will continue to update the list of symptoms as more is learned. You can check your symptoms with the CDC's self-checker tool.
Not everyone with COVID-19 has a fever. Even mild symptoms (like a headache or dry cough) could be signs of COVID-19.
Not everyone infected with the COVID-19 virus has symptoms. People with COVID-19 who don't have any symptoms can spread the virus to other people. Learn how to protect yourself and others.
All Vermonters, even with mild symptoms, are encouraged to contact their health care provider to get tested. Your provider will test you at their office or refer you for testing nearby. Stay home while waiting for your result.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Learn more about what to do if you have COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I donât have an email address. How do I schedule an appointment?
answerText:
If you donât have an email address, you can call 855-722-7878 to schedule your appointment over the phone. However, you will not get an appointment reminder since those are being sent by email. The call center is open Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.
Another option would be to ask a family member to create an online account with their email address. Your family member will be able to add you as a âdependentâ to schedule and assist with managing your appointments. Learn more about making an appointment for someone else.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What kind of assistance will be available at my vaccine appointment? Can someone come with me?
answerText:
All vaccine clinics will be handicap accessible. Wheelchairs are available at all Health Department vaccination sites and at hospitals.
Language interpreters (including ASL) can be arranged at Health Department vaccination sites. Usually, the interpreter will work with you remotely by phone or video conference through a computer available at the site. To request an interpreter, ask one of the public health workers at the site. Some sites, including Burlington and Winooski, will have in-person interpreters based on demand for these services in the area.
If you need physical assistance getting to your vaccine appointment, you can have one other person come with you. You will both have your temperatures taken and will be asked questions to determine if you have any current COVID-19 symptoms. If either of you do, then the person who has symptoms wonât be allowed to go any further.
You will both need to wear masks during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be masks available at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove your mask by yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.
Find out what to do if you need a ride to your appointment.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What can I expect at my vaccine appointment?
answerText:
You will need to wear a mask during your appointment. If you do not have one, there will be one available for you at the clinic. If you have trouble breathing, are unable to remove it yourself, or have a medical reason for not wearing one, you will not be required to wear a mask.
Remember to dress warmly for the weather.Â Arrive on time so you donât have to wait long, or keep others waiting.Â Please do not arrive earlier than 15 minutes before your appointment. If you need someone to come with you for assistance, please only bring one person so we can limit the number of people inside the clinics and make sure people are properly distanced.
Once you arrive at the vaccine clinic, here is what will happen:

Before you enter the clinic, someone will take your temperature and ask questions to determine if you have any current symptoms of COVID-19. If you do, then you will be asked to reschedule your appointment.
You will go inside and check in. You will be asked to fill out paperwork, which will include a health screening questionnaire.
You will be asked to go to a vaccination station where you will get the vaccine in your arm.
You will be given a handout with information about the vaccine you got and any possible side effects to watch out for, as well as how to report any reactions or side effects you may have.
You will be asked to stay for 15 to 30 minutes so you can be watched for any side effects.
Someone will help you schedule an appointment to get your second dose of vaccine at a later date.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I donât have my own transportation. Can I get a ride to my vaccine appointment?
answerText:
Yes. Free public transportation to vaccine clinics is available to Vermont residents who do not have their own transportation. Rides are coordinated by the Vermont Public Transportation Association. Volunteer drivers will use cars, vans or buses. All rides are ADA compliant and will accommodate people living with disabilities.
Please make a request at least 48 hours before your vaccine appointment. These rides are subject to the availability of transportation resources, so advance notice is necessary to make sure you will have a ride.
Rides are only available if you are not sick with COVID-19 (with symptoms or without symptoms) or are not a close contact of someone who has COVID-19. If you recently traveled, you need to follow the current travel quarantine requirements before you can request a ride. If you fall into one of these categories, you will need to answer some questions to find out when you can use public transportation.
Find contact information for your local public transportation provider.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Does being vaccinated affect my COVID-19 test results?
answerText:
No. The COVID-19 vaccines that are available and the other vaccines currently in clinical trials in the United States will not cause you to test positive on viral tests. PCR and antigen tests are viral tests, and will tell you if you are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus.
If your body develops an immune response, which is what happens when you get vaccinated, there is a possibility you may test positive on some antibody tests. Antibody, or serologic, tests measure the bodyâs immune response to the virus and show that you may have some level of protection against the virus. Experts are currently looking at how getting the COVID-19 vaccine may affect antibody testing results.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I need to use the same account I made to get a COVID-19 test to schedule a vaccine appointment?
answerText:
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The registration system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.
Once you log in, click on the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and follow the prompts on the screen. You can also watch a video on how to schedule an appointment.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I make two appointments for COVID-19 vaccination at the same time, for example for both my parents or myself and my spouse?
answerText:
You will need to register each person individually. We can only register one person for an appointment at a time online and through the call center. This is because each slot and series of questions apply just to one person.
If you are making an appointment online, you can either create an account for each person, or create a single account and add the other person to the account by clicking on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen (follow the prompts in the registration system). You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address. Find out what you will need and how to make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
If you are making an appointment by phone, you can also make more than one appointment. We will do our best to get the appointments as close together as possible, but they may not be at the same time. Call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do I do if my COVID-19 test is inconclusive?
answerText: An âinconclusiveâ or âindeterminateâ result means the test was neither positive nor negative. If you receive a test result that is âinconclusiveâ or âindeterminate,â the Health Department encourages you to get retested. Find out where to get tested.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Should I be vaccinated if I have or had COVID-19?
answerText:
If you had COVID-19 and are recovered, you may be vaccinated or choose to defer for up to 90 days. Evidence suggests that getting infected again in 90 days after is uncommon.
If you currently have COVID-19, please wait until you have recovered before being vaccinated.
If you had monoclonal antibodies or convalescent plasma as part of COVID-19 treatment, wait for at least 90 days before getting your vaccination to avoid interfering with your treatment.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Should I get the vaccine if I have a medical condition?
answerText:
In clinical studies, COVID-19 vaccines were just as effective for people with and without medical conditions. In fact, people with some conditions are more likely to get very sick if they get COVID-19, so getting vaccinated could be even more important. If you are unsure if you should get the vaccine, talk to your health care provider about any conditions you have. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Learn more about vaccination if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.
Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How do I know if my symptoms are from the vaccine or sickness from COVID-19?
answerText:
It takes time for the vaccine to teach your body to fight COVID-19, so you may not be protected by the vaccine until a few weeks after your second dose. This is one of the reasons it is so important to continue prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, even after youâve been vaccinated.
It may be hard to tell the difference between side effects from the vaccine and symptoms from sickness if you get infected with COVID-19 between vaccine doses. While everyoneâs reaction may be different, vaccine side effects usually start within 12 to 24 hours after your vaccination. They should go away within a few days.
If symptoms get worse or last longer than a few days, contact your health care provider. They should be able to suggest next steps and maybe a COVID-19 test. Getting the vaccine will not affect your COVID-19 test results.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What happens if a vaccine clinic is canceled due to weather?
answerText:
Check your local news station or the Health Departmentâs website and social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) for any changes to Health Department vaccine clinic schedules due to weather.
If the Health Department vaccine clinic is not canceled but youâd like to reschedule your appointment because of the weather, call 855-722-7878.
If you registered to get your vaccine at Kinney Drugs, contact the store where your appointment is to find out if the clinic will be open or how to reschedule.
No matter what, you should always watch the weather and stay home if you don't feel safe traveling. There are enough vaccine appointments for everyone who is eligible â we will get you rescheduled if needed.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I take medicines before or after my vaccine?
answerText:
If you regularly take pain relievers like aspirin, acetaminophen (for example, Tylenol) or ibuprofen (for example, Motrin, Advil), allergy or other medications for medical conditions, please continue to do so as directed by your health care provider or as needed.
Do not take pain relievers or allergy medication before you get the vaccine to avoid side effects or allergic reactions. Allergy medications do not prevent a serious allergic reaction. They may hide symptoms that would tell a health care provider to treat an allergic reaction. Pain relievers may limit the vaccine from making a strong immune response.
After your vaccine, you can take pain relievers for any side effects you may have from the vaccine to help you feel better.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: When will I receive my test results?
answerText:
Test results will be available typically within 3 business days. Business days are Monday through Friday. If you were tested on a Wednesday, Thursday or Friday, your results may not be posted until the following week. Holidays are not considered business days. Find out what to do while youâre waiting for your test results and how to get your results.
How you receive results varies depending on where you were tested.
If you were tested at a Health Department testing site (for people without symptoms) and:

you requested an electronic result, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready. You can then log in to your COVID-19 testing account to get the result. You will not receive a letter.
you requested a letter, you can expect to receive it within 7 business days. If you also provided an email address, you can expect an email within 3 business days, when your result is ready. You can then log in to your COVID-19 testing account to get the result.
If you do not have a COVID-19 testing account (you attended the testing event as a walk-in) a patient ID was created for you and sent to the email you provided. You will need to use the link in the email to confirm your patient ID. Once you confirm the patient ID, you can log in to your COVID-19 testing account and view your test results once they are available, which will be within 3 business days.

Call 802-863-7240 option 9 if you are having problems accessing your test results.
The Health Department only uses a PCR test. We cannot guarantee that you will receive your results in less than 3 business days. We also cannot accommodate special requests for receiving test results or rush results. Find the list of Health Department testing sites.
If you have a positive result, our contact tracing team will talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
If you got tested anywhere else, the Health Department cannot provide your results. Please contact your health care provider if they ordered the test, or the facility that conducted the test.
If you were tested before an inpatient or outpatient procedure, you will receive your test results before your procedure from the health care provider who is doing the procedure.
If you received a positive result, the Health Department will also reach out to talk to you about public health recommendations and ask questions about people you were in contact with. It is possible that the Health Department may contact you before your health care provider does.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am having problems making an appointment for testing or receiving my test results. Who do I contact?
answerText:
If you have questions or need help creating an account, scheduling an appointment, or if you have questions about receiving your test results, please call 802-863-7240 option 9.
The COVID-19 Event Portal is used for both testing and vaccine registration. Log in to your account.
Find out what to do if you are having problems making an appointment for your vaccine.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How soon after being exposed to someone with COVID-19, or after attending a gathering, should I get tested?
answerText:
The incubation period for the COVID-19 virus is 2 to 14 days. This means that it can take 2 to 14 days after being exposed to get symptoms or to test positive. We recommend you get tested twice â as soon as 2 days after the exposure or gathering and again 7 days after the exposure or gathering if you:

think you have been exposed to someone with COVID-19
are a close contact
have gathered with people you donât live with

For your initial test, if the result is negative, you will need to remain in quarantine and follow guidance provided by the Health Department. If the result is positive, you must follow isolation guidance provided by the Health Department.
Getting tested right away means you may be able to find out if you have COVID-19 early. This initial test also helps the Health Department find other people who have COVID-19 more quickly.
Getting tested before day 7 cannot be used to end quarantine early. Read about the option to end quarantine early by getting tested on day 7 or later. Learn about why it is okay to end quarantine early.
Check out this timeline for close contacts of people with COVID-19.
Find out what to do if you think you had close contact with someone who has COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Should I get a COVID-19 vaccine with other vaccines?
answerText: The COVID-19 vaccine should be given alone. Wait at least 14 days between the COVID-19 vaccine and other vaccines, including the shingles vaccine.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is known about Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19?
answerText:
According to the CDC, Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a condition where different body parts can become inflamed, including the heart, lungs, kidneys, brain, skin, eyes, or gastrointestinal organs. We do not yet know what causes MIS-C. However, many children with MIS-C had the COVID-19 virus, or had been around someone with COVID-19. MIS-C can be serious, even deadly, but most children who were diagnosed with this condition have gotten better with medical care.
If your child is experiencing symptoms of MIS-C, call their primary care provider right away. MIS-C appears to be rare both worldwide and, in the U.S., and most children with this syndrome have responded well to supportive treatment.
There have been several reports of a similar multisystem inflammatory syndrome in adults (MIS-A). Learn more about MIS-A from the CDC.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I volunteer to help with the Stateâs response to COVID-19?
answerText:
People with medical or other health care, mental health or other clinical experience, health care administrative experience (translators, medical data entry), or who have experience working with displaced people can volunteer with Vermont's Medical Reserve Corps. Learn how to join the Medical Reserve Corps and find frequently asked questions.
Nurses and caregivers, both paid and volunteer are needed to support Vermont's long-term care facilities provide direct care and support. People with other skills (for example, drivers, food service, construction, IT, security, skilled trades, etc.) from across different sectors and disciplines to are needed to keep our essential infrastructure operational. Find paid or volunteer opportunities.
Vermont has eased licensing requirements for the purpose of helping out with the COVID-19 response. Learn more about getting a temporary license if you are a health professional.
Here are other ways you can help:

Donate blood with the American Red Cross.
Support your local Foodbank by volunteering or donating online, or you can text GIVEHEALTH to 85511.
Donate or volunteer with community organizations or emergency supply efforts.
Help your neighbors â older adults and at-risk people need to stay home as much as possible. Offer to go shopping for them or keep them company by phone.

When volunteering please follow the guidelines on being a good neighbor.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am having problems registering for my vaccine appointment. Who do I contact?
answerText:
If you have questions or need help creating an account, scheduling an appointment, or signing up someone as a dependent, please call 855-722-7878.
The COVID-19 Event Portal is used for both testing and vaccine registration. Log in to your account.
Find out what to do if you are having problems making an appointment for testing or have questions about your test results.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Why do I need two doses of the vaccine?
answerText:
Both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines require two doses, spaced about 3 to 4 weeks apart. We strongly recommend Vermonters get both doses for the highest level of protection from COVID-19.
Two doses of these vaccines are scientifically proven to be highly effective in preventing COVID-19. Since the beginning, we have followed the science. Participants in the clinical trials who did not receive both doses were not followed for a long period of time, so we do not know for sure how well or how long one dose will protect you.
A two-dose vaccine is not new. For some vaccines, like hepatitis B, shingles and HPV, two doses produce longer-lasting protection. While the first dose gets your immune system ready and offers some protection, the second dose boosts that protection by using your bodyâs new immune cells it created after the first dose. This âboosterâ increases the strength of your new antibody protection and makes it last longer.
Taking the full course of vaccine offers better protection against variants of the virus. In fact, being only partially vaccinated, for example getting only one dose of a two-dose vaccine, could increase the risk of vaccine-resistant variants of the virus that causes COVID-19. This is because the virus could be weakened with some antibody protection, but not stopped completely, creating the potential for the virus to mutate.
Some people experience stronger side effects after the second shot. Both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines have equal doses in their first and second shots, but for some, stronger side effects are part of their bodyâs normal immune reaction to that âboostâ in protection. Common side effects reported were pain at the injection site, fever, chills, tiredness and headache. These side effects typically go away within a few days.
Whether you experience side effects or not, rest assured the vaccine is working to protect you, your family and your community.
Find out when you need to get your second shot.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How can I make my own cloth mask?
answerText:
Homemade cloth masks can be made using simple materials found in most homes, for example, an old t-shirt or bandanna and rubber bands or hair ties. Make your mask with two or more layers of washable, breathable fabric.
The CDC has instructions on how to make a mask in several different methods, including machine or hand-sewn, a no-sew method with a t-shirt and scissors, and a no-sew method with a bandana.
You are required to wear a mask in public spaces in Vermont. In private settings (for example, at a gathering with family and friends in your backyard or riding in a car), we recommend that you a mask anytime you're around people you donât live with.
Learn more:

Wearing face masks to keep COVID-19 from spreading
Face coverings for children
CDCâs guide to masks â how to choose, wear, store and wash masks

The State of Vermont is offering a limited number of free cloth masks to the public. Find out if free cloth masks are available in your area.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What can I wear if my health or work environment doesn't allow me to wear a cloth face mask or covering?
answerText:
The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly throughÂ close contact, by respiratory droplets released when people with COVID-19 cough, sneeze, sing, talk, or breathe.Â Face shields are typically used in health care settings to protect the person wearing them from droplets getting into their eyes. Masks or coverings, like a cloth mask or bandanna, do a better job than face shields of keeping droplets in and not spreading the virus.
However, if your work environment or health does not allow you to wear a mask, wearing a face shield is better than having no barrier over your nose and mouth.
Make sure your face shield fits properly. Face shields should extend below the chin, to the ears on both sides, and there should be no exposed gap between the forehead and the shieldâs headpiece. Clean them regularly â especially if condensation or droplets are visible on the inside of the shield â and handle them like masks when putting them on or removing them.
People who have trouble breathing can wear a light-weight bandanna or cloth covering tied to be open at the bottom, or a face shield.
Outdoor workers who are doing strenuous work that causes heavy breathing are not required to wear a mask when it is hot outside. Workers should keep masks with them and wear them when they are not exerting themselves (for example talking, resting, or interacting with other co-workers or people). It is important that workers keep a 6-foot distance from others whenever possible, especially when they are not wearing a mask.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How can I confirm my vaccine appointment? Will I receive a confirmation?
answerText:
If you made an appointment online or by phone, you will be sent an email confirmation to the email address you provided. You can also log in to your account to see the appointment date, time and location for yourself or for a dependent or spouse.
If you donât have an email address, you will not receive a confirmation. You can call 855-722-7878 to confirm your appointment date, time and location if you donât have an email address, or if you are having trouble accessing the online system.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What should I know about side effects?
answerText:
Side effects from the vaccine are normal signs that your body is building protection against COVID-19. They might even affect your daily activities but should go away in a few days. Common side effects are:

Pain, swelling or redness on the arm where you got the shot
Tiredness
Headache
Chills
Muscle or joint pain
Fever
Nausea or vomiting

What to do about side effects:

Call your health care or vaccine provider if side effects are worrying you or if they donât go away after a few days.
You can use V-safe to tell the CDC about any side effects and to get reminders for your second dose. V-safe is an optional smartphone tool that uses text messages and web surveys to provide personalized check-ins. Learn more and register for V-safe. If you donât have a smartphone, a family member can sign up for you.
If you have a bad reaction after getting vaccinated, you or your health care provider can report it to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS). Call 1-800-822-7967 or report it online.

Learn about why it is important to get two doses of the vaccine.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Is one type of mask better than another? Is wearing two masks better?
answerText:
The most important thing to do is to wear a mask â period. Wearing a mask protects both you and the people around you from getting or spreading COVID-19.
There are several types of masks to choose from, including cloth, disposable, N95 and KN95.
According to the CDC, the most effective fabrics for cloth masks are:

tightly woven fabrics, such as cotton and cotton blends
breathable
two or three fabric layers

You can also wear a disposable mask, like a surgical or medical procedure mask, instead of a cloth mask, now that they are in greater supply. These masks may provide some additional protection.
The CDC has found that âdouble maskingâ or wearing two masks (disposable mask underneath and a cloth mask on top) can offer a better fit and provide extra protection.
Typically N95 masks should be reserved for health care workers who are at highest risk and need them most. KN95 masks are also available for the public to purchase, but make sure the mask has been approved by the Food & Drug Administration.
Whichever mask you choose, it is important to make sure it fits properly. Learn more from the CDC about improving how your mask protects you.
The CDC continues to study the effectiveness of different types of masks, and we will update our recommendations as new scientific evidence becomes available.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Where do people living with a substance use disorder go for information on treatment and recovery services?
answerText:
VT Helplink is a resource for Vermonters to receive free, confidential and personalized information and referrals to substance use prevention, treatment and recovery services throughout the state.
VTHelplink features a call center of trained staff and clinicians. Callers can get information, referrals, resources and educational materials on substance use for themselves, family and friends, or on behalf of clients.
The VTHelplink website has information resources and an online screening tool to help Vermonters learn about treatment options that meet their needs. People can also securely chat online with call center staff through the website.
Hereâs how you can reach VTHelplink:

Dial 802-565-LINK (5465). The call center is open 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. weekdays, and 8 a.m to 6 p.m. on weekends and holidays, 365 days per year.
Visit vthelplink.org.

You can also find information on how to decrease the spread of COVID-19 among people who attend in-person recovery meetings that are independent of Recovery Centers.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What information is available for health care providers and workers?
answerText:
The Health Department has guidance and information for health care professionals. It includes current guidance for the health care community, including health alerts, testing information, vaccine information and resources for protecting patients and health care workers in different settings.
Report all suspected cases of COVID-19 immediately to the Vermont Department of Health Infectious Disease Epidemiology by calling 802-863-7240 (24/7).
If you suspect that a patient with a fever or respiratory illness has COVID-19:

Give the patient a surgical mask.
Notify facility infection control personnel immediately.
Use standard precautions, contact precautions, airborne precautions, and use eye protection when entering the room.
Evaluate the patient in a private room with the door closed, ideally in an airborne infection isolation room.

Health care providers are encouraged to order a test for any child or adult who is showing symptoms of COVID-19, even if their symptoms are mild. Health care providers can test them in their office or refer them to a centralized testing site. Find more testing information for health care professionals.
COVID-19 activity in the community may affect how facilities and providers make decisions about testing, operations and personal protective equipment (PPE). Find information for health care providers, nursing homes and other long-term care facilities to make decisions based on measures of community-level burden.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do I do if I test positive for COVID-19?
answerText:
You will need to isolate if you test positive for COVID-19. Isolation means you need to stay home and away from other people, until you have recovered. This is to prevent further spread of the virus. A contact tracer will call you to give you guidance. They will answer any questions you may have and see if you need help getting resources to stay home.
Most people with mild illness can recover at home. While there is no specific treatment for COVID-19, you should get plenty of rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take fever-reducing medication if needed.
If you or a family member are sick, follow these steps to care for yourself and to help protect other people in your home and your community:

Stay home, except to get medical care. Call ahead before visiting your health care provider. Anyone who does not have a health care provider can call 2-1-1 to be connected to care or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics.
Separate yourself from other people and pets.
Monitor your symptoms.
Wear a mask when you're around people and pets.
Cover your coughs and sneezes with your sleeve or a tissue. Then throw the tissue in the trash.
Wash your hands often. Use an alcohol-based sanitizer if soap and water aren't available.
Avoid sharing personal household items.
Clean all high-touch surfaces in your home daily.
Get support from others. Stay in touch with family and friends by phone, email or online platform.
Monitor your blood oxygen levels. People diagnosed with COVID-19 may have below-normal levels of oxygen in their blood before they feel short of breath. Finding low oxygen levels early can help you know to seek medical care sooner. This could make the disease less severe. Learn more about this program.

Learn more about what to do if you test positive for COVID-19.
Learn more from the CDC:

What to do if you are sick
10 things you can do to manage your COVID-19 symptoms at home
Caring for newborns when parents have COVID-19
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What does a "pending" test result mean?
answerText: "Pending" means that your test results are not yet ready. Test results will be available typically within 3 business days. Business days are Monday through Friday. If your test was more than 3 business days ago and your test result is still listed as pending, please call 802-863-7240 option 9.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is an antigen test?
answerText:
An antigen test for COVID-19 is a type of test that identifies people who are currently infected with the COVID-19 virus. Antigen tests provide results much more quickly than PCR tests (the most common type of test used to diagnose and confirm COVID-19 infection). Antigen tests are sometimes referred to as rapid (fast) tests.
Antigen tests are usually less sensitive than PCR tests, so they might miss some cases. Antigen tests could be more useful in certain circumstances:

For people who have symptoms of COVID-19. So far, studies on antigen tests have only been done on people with symptoms, and we do not have evidence about the accuracy of the antigen test on people without symptoms.
Health care providers may use antigen testing when PCR testing is not available or when results are needed quickly. This may be when people who are having symptoms get tested at their doctorâs office or when patients are being admitted to hospitals that donât have a lot of PCR tests available.
Antigen tests may be used to screen people to identify those who need a more definitive test. Antigen tests are particularly helpful when used to test people in the early stages of infection (within the first 5 to 7 days of having COVID-19 symptoms) when the viral load is generally the highest. For example, long-term care facilities could screen residents and staff who are not having symptoms, but only if the tests were done at least weekly.
For surveillance purposes, to see what COVID-19 activity might be occurring in a community.

When used to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, antigen tests have a higher chance of missing an active infection than PCR tests. This means that if you have symptoms, you may receive a negative result but still be infected with COVID-19.
Antigen tests are different from antibody (serologic) tests, which identify people who have previously been infected with the COVID-19 virus and do not show whether a person is currently infected.
Learn more:

Use of Antigen Testing in Vermont â Health Update October 1, 2020
Coronavirus testing basics from the Food and Drug Administration
Considerations for Implementation of SARS-CoV-2 Rapid Antigen Testing from the Association of Public Health Laboratories.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do managers and owners of apartment complexes need to do?
answerText: There is guidance for managers and owners of apartment complexes to help prevent the spread of COVID-19, which includes information for making a plan, preparing common spaces and communicating with residents or staff, in addition to outlining the role of the Health Department.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I have recovered from COVID-19, but I am sick with a new illness and symptoms. When can I return to work, school or child care?
answerText:
If you develop new illness symptoms within the first 3 months of recovering from a COVID-19 infection, we do not recommend retesting. Data to date show that a person who has had and recovered from COVID-19 may have low levels of virus in their bodies for up to 3 months after diagnosis. This means that if the person who has recovered from COVID-19 is retested within 3 months of their initial infection, they may continue to have a positive test result, even though they are not spreading COVID-19.
You should still stay home when you are sick to prevent spreading illness to others. You should remain home until your symptoms have improved or are gone. If you have a fever, you should stay home until you are fever-free (without the use of fever-reducing medicine) for at least 24 hours. Contact your health care provider if you have questions or concerns.
Learn more about if people who recover from COVID-19 can be infected again and when you are considered to be recovered from COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I had COVID-19. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
answerText:
If you had COVID-19 â and then are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19) â you do not need to quarantine only if:

you had a positive COVID-19 test result (from a PCR or antigen test) and have met the criteria to end your isolation, and
the new exposure is within the first 3 months after symptoms from your initial infection started, or within the first 3 months of your first positive test if you didnât have symptoms during your initial infection, and
you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.

However, you must quarantineÂ when you travel or return to Vermont under theÂ current travel guidelines and you are not allowed to gatherÂ with people you donât live with under theÂ current social gathering guidelines.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I live in a border town. Do I need to quarantine if I travel to and from towns across the border?
answerText:
A border town is considered a town that is within 5 miles of the Vermont border. Many of Vermontâs border towns are economically and culturally linked to a neighboring stateâs border towns. Vermontâs cross state travel guidance allows people to travel between border towns for certain purposes without quarantining. This means that if you are a Vermonter living in a border town or if you live in a border town in a neighboring state, you do not need to quarantine only if:

You travel 5 miles into a neighboring state or into Vermont.
You travel to a neighboring state or to Vermont and back home in the same day.
You travel for an essential purpose or for an activity that is necessary for your physical or mental health. This includes going to worship, going to a gym, getting a haircut, and participating in place-based outdoor recreation. This does not include activities such as social gatherings, dining at a restaurant or bar, or going to an indoor entertainment venue (for example, a movie theater or bowling alley).

You must continue to follow the COVID-19 prevention measures, including wearing a mask and staying at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with, when you are in a border town in Vermont or in a neighboring state.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How long does protection from the vaccine last?
answerText:
According to the CDC, we donât know how long protection lasts for those who are vaccinated. What we do know is that COVID-19 has caused very serious illness and death for a lot of people. If you get COVID-19, you also risk giving it to loved ones who may get very sick. Getting a COVID-19 vaccine is a safer choice.
Experts are working to learn more about both natural immunity and immunity from being vaccinated. The CDC will keep the public informed as new evidence becomes available.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How long does it take for the vaccine to protect me from getting COVID-19?
answerText:
You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. It takes time for the vaccine to train your body to fight COVID-19.
The vaccine protects you from serious illness, but we donât know for sure if you can give the virus to someone else. Some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, it is important to continue following the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, and to follow the social gathering guidelines, even after youâve been vaccinated.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I still infect someone with the COVID-19 virus after I've been fully vaccinated?
answerText:
You may not be protected from COVID-19 until you are fully vaccinated, which is 14 days after your final shot. While the vaccine protects you from serious illness, we donât know yet if you can give the virus to someone else.
However, some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until more research is done, it is important that you continue to follow the prevention steps, like wearing a mask, keeping 6 feet apart, and washing your hands, and to follow the social gathering guidelines, even after youâve been vaccinated.
Learn more about the studies:

Decreased SARS-CoV-2 viral load following vaccination
Transmission of COVID-19 in 282 clusters in Catalonia, Spain: a cohort study
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How much does the COVID-19 vaccine cost?
answerText:
COVID-19 vaccines are free. COVID-19 vaccines are provided to Vermonters at no cost, even if you donât have health insurance.
You are guaranteed a COVID-19 vaccine without paying a fee. The provider that gives you your vaccine may charge an administrative fee to your insurance. If you donât have insurance, there is a federal grant that will pay for any administrative fees.
When you make an appointment to be vaccinated, you will be asked to provide your health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and someone who doesnât have insurance will still be able to get a vaccine. But being able to bill someoneâs primary insurance does help offset some of the costs.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am not able to leave my home. How can I get the vaccine?
answerText:
Homebound means you are not able to leave your home for scheduled medical or non-medical appointments. If you are currently eligible to get the vaccine and are homebound, you will be able to get the vaccine in your home.
If you are in the service of a local home health agency, the agency will reach out to you to schedule an appointment.
If you are not in the service of a home health agency, you may request an appointment by calling 802-863-7240 (toll-free 833-722-0860) Monday through Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.
Please do not make a request if you have already made one through your primary care provider, hospital, or home health agency. There is enough vaccine for everyone who is homebound. However, it will take time to reach everyone in need. In most cases, your appointment will be scheduled 10 to 14 days after you make a request.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What can I do after I am fully vaccinated?
answerText:
You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Until you are fully vaccinated, you should follow the same guidance as unvaccinated people. Learn about why it is important to get two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccine.
Continue Prevention
Continue takingÂ steps to prevent COVID-19, except as described below.
The vaccine protects you from illness, but we donât know for sure if you can give the virus to someone else. Some recent studies suggest that a person who is vaccinated is less likely to infect other people with the COVID-19 virus. Until enough people are vaccinated and we know more, it is important to continue to follow prevention steps and continue to wear a mask, keep 6 feet apart, and wash your hands.
Gathering with Others
The following guidance only applies in non-health care settings.

You may gather with other fully vaccinated people indoors without wearing masks or staying 6 feet apart.
You may also gather with unvaccinated people from one household indoors without wearing masks or staying 6 feet apart, as long as everyone in that household is at low risk for severe COVID-19.

If you gather with people from more than one unvaccinated household, or with someone who is at higher risk of severe COVID-19, you must wear a mask and keep a 6-foot distance. SeeÂ details on gathering restrictions in Vermont.
Travel
You may travel to or return to Vermont without quarantine. Find outÂ more about travel, includingÂ staying in someone's home.
Close Contact of Someone with COVID-19
If you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19, as long as you do not have symptoms and are not in a health care setting:

You do not need to seek testing.
You do not need to quarantine.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am fully vaccinated. Do I need to quarantine if I am a close contact of someone with COVID-19?
answerText:
