No. You do not need to quarantine if it has been 14 days since you got your final vaccine dose, and then you are exposed to someone with COVID-19 (for example, you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19),Â and you have not had any COVID-19 symptoms since the new exposure.
However, vaccinated inpatients and residents in health care settings will still need to quarantine if they are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. Read the CDCâs guidance.
This guidance does not apply to health care workers in certain situations.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How many people are being monitored in Vermont?
answerText: You can find information about Vermontâs COVID-19 vaccination progress on the COVID-19 Vaccine Dashboard, including the number of doses received, total people started, total people completed, percentage of overall progress and percentage completed. The dashboard is updated Tuesdays through Saturdays.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again?
answerText:
People who haveÂ recoveredÂ from COVID-19 can be infected again. Current data show that a person who had COVID-19 and recovered from it may have small amounts of the virusâs genetic materials in their body for at least three months after they were diagnosed with COVID-19. This means that if you have recovered from COVID-19 and are tested within three months of your initial infection, you may continue to have a positive test result.
The likelihood of a person being reinfected with COVID-19 within three months of their initial infection is low. Research regarding this is ongoing. Therefore, if you have recovered from COVID-19 and have new symptoms of COVID-19, you may need to be evaluated to see if you have COVID-19 again, especially if you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19. In this case, you should isolate and contact your health care provider to be evaluated for other causes of your symptoms, and possibly retested.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What are the current restrictions on gatherings?
answerText:
Vermont has restrictions on social gatherings based on whether you are fully vaccinated or not. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Since children cannot get vaccinated at this time, a household with children is not considered a fully vaccinated household.
If you are fully vaccinated:

You may gather with other fully vaccinated people or households. You donât need to wear a mask or stay 6 feet apart when you gather.
You may gather with up to two unvaccinated people or households at a time. The gathering can also include other vaccinated people or households. If you gather with people from more than one unvaccinated household, or with someone who is at higher risk of severe COVID-19 or lives with someone at higher risk, everyone should wear a mask and stay 6 feet apart.

If you are not fully vaccinated:

You may gather with fully vaccinated people or households. You donât need to wear a mask or stay 6 feet apart, unless someone is at higher risk of severe COVID-19 or lives with someone at higher risk.
You may gather with one other unvaccinated person or household at a time. Fully vaccinated people or households can also be at the gathering. Everyone should wear a mask and stay 6 feet apart.
You can do outdoor recreation and fitness activities with anyone. This includes biking, hiking, walking, running, hunting and fishing, skiing, snowboarding, skating, snow machining and other no-contact outdoor activities. However, you must stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and wear a mask at all times. Do not gather at trailheads, access areas or other outdoor facilities before or after the activity.
If you live alone, you may gather with people who live in one other household.
You can take in and shelter people from another household who are living in a dangerous, unhealthy or otherwise unsafe situation.

If you are a visitor traveling to Vermont and staying at a lodging establishment, short-term rental, or with friends and family, must follow these gathering restrictions. Staying with another household is considered a social gathering and you must follow the rules listed above. Learn more about Vermonters hosting visitors in their homes.
It is not considered a social gathering if you have contact with someone for less than 15 minutes, you both are wearing masks, and you stay at least 6 feet apart (for example, checking on a neighbor, friend or family member not in your household). You are allowed to come in contact with members of other households in settings that continue to operate â such as schools, workplaces, retail stores, close contact businesses, etc. â as long as all the required health protocols are followed.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is known about variants of the COVID-19 virus?
answerText:
Viruses constantly change through mutation, and new variants of a virus are expected to occur over time. Information about these variants is rapidly emerging. Scientists are working to learn more about how easily they spread, whether they could cause more severe illness, and whether currently authorized vaccines will protect people against them.
Multiple COVID-19 variants are circulating globally, namely in the United Kingdom (UK), South Africa and Brazil. According to the CDC, these variants seem to spread more easily and quickly than other variants, which may lead to more cases of COVID-19. You can find a map showing the number of confirmed cases caused by variants in the U.S.
The Health Department is working to detect any potential variants of concern â through genetic sequencing of certain specimens taken from various parts of the state and through wastewater testing in Burlington. We will continue this work, to help Vermonters understand any changes in the virus that may require us to strengthen our prevention efforts.
Here is what you can do to protect yourself and your community:

Keep up with prevention steps, like wearing masks, staying 6 feet apart, staying home if you are sick, washing your hands often, and avoiding crowded places. Prevention steps continue to be effective against variants.
Get tested if you think you have been exposed to COVID-19 or if you think you have any symptoms, even if they are mild. While a test is not able to determine if a variant is present, knowing that you have COVID-19 as soon as possible will help protect yourself and your community.
Get vaccinated when you are eligible. So far, studies suggest that the vaccines available now will help our bodies fight against strains of the virus that causes COVID-19.

Variants in Vermont

The B.1.1.7 variant, first identified in the UK, has now been detected in many U.S. states, including Vermont. The CDC anticipates the more easily transmissible B.1.1.7 variant will become the dominant strain in the country.
The B.1.429 variant, first identified in California, has been detected in Vermont.

Learn more about what we know, what we donât know, and what the CDC is doing about variants of the COVID-19 virus.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I make a vaccine appointment for someone else? How do I sign someone up as a dependent?
answerText:
Yes. You can make an appointment for your loved one or someone you care for who is currently eligible, especially if they need help creating an account and making an appointment online.
Anyone who is unable to make their appointment online, needs help, or who wants to speak with someone in a language other than English can call 855-722-7878.
If you are making an appointment online for a spouse or partner at the same time as your own, you will need to make the appointments individually. Learn more about making two appointments at the same time.
If you are a case worker who is scheduling an appointment for your client, please call 855-722-7878 Monday through Friday from 8:15 a.m. â 5:30 p.m. and Saturday to Sunday 10:00 a.m. â 3:00 p.m.
If you are scheduling an appointment for a family member, we recommend that you create an account, and then sign them up as a âdependent.â You can watch a video on how to make an appointment online and find tips for making an appointment. Here are the steps you will need to take:
1. Create an account.
First, you will need to create an account in our online system. You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.
If you already have an account, start at the âadd a dependentâ step below.
Here is how you create an account:

Go to the COVID-19 Event Portal.
Enter your name, phone number, email address, and date of birth.
Click the âcreate accountâ button.

After you create an account, an email is immediately sent to the email address you entered. You will need to verify your account on the COVID-19 Event Portal to make the personâs appointment:

Click on the link in the email sent to you to confirm your account.
Enter your Patient ID number.
Enter your email and date of birth.
Create a password.
Review and consent to the Notice of Privacy Practices.
Enter your personal demographic information.
Enter your vaccine eligibility information, including your pass code (if applicable).

2. Add a dependent.
You will need to add them as a dependent. You can watch a video on how to add a dependent to your account. Click on the âAdd Dependent/Spouseâ button at the top of the screen. After consenting, you will need to enter their personal information:

Name
Email address (use your email, the same one used to set up your account)
Phone number
Select how you would like to receive communication and documents from the Health Department.
Date of birth
Address
Enter their vaccine eligibility information, including their pass code (if applicable).

If the person getting the vaccine does not live in Vermont, the system will ask do they work in Vermont, get primary care in Vermont, or recently moved to Vermont. If none of these apply, they wonât be able to get vaccinated in Vermont, and should seek a vaccine in the state where they live.
3. Schedule a vaccine appointment.
Click the âSchedule Vaccine Appointmentâ button at the top of the screen and select their name. Select a clinic site location by searching by county and date range.
Next, you will answer a series of medical (see below) and demographic questions as well as questions about any COVID-19 symptoms the person has. You will be asked to provide their health insurance information. Insurance is not required, and there is no cost for getting the vaccine. You also will be asked to complete a waiver.
Finally, choose an appointment slot from the list of available appointments. Click the âsubmitâ button. You may be redirected to choose a different location and time depending on your vaccine eligibility. Once you make an appointment, you will immediately receive an email confirmation.
These are the medical screening questions asked:

Have you had a severe allergic reaction (e.g., anaphylaxis) after a previous dose of the Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine or any of its components? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a vaccine. They should consider contacting their health care provider if they have questions.
Have you had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine or injectable therapy? If the answer is yes, then they will be asked to contact their health care provider for a referral to an allergy/immunology specialist who can determine if they can safely receive the vaccine.
Are you currently sick with COVID-19 or still in your isolation period following a COVID-19 infection? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
Have you had a vaccine in the past 14 days or is a vaccination scheduled in the next 8 weeks? If the answer is yes, then they cannot get a COVID-19 vaccine at this time, but can schedule an appointment at a later date.
Have you received passive antibody therapy as treatment for COVID-19 in the past 90 days? If the answer is yes, then they will need to wait for 90 days before scheduling an appointment.
Do you have a weakened immune system caused by something such as HIV infection or cancer or do you take immunosuppressive drugs or therapies? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
Are you pregnant? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
Are you lactating or breastfeeding? If the answer is yes, they can make an appointment, but they will be advised to talk with their health care provider before getting vaccinated.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is self-observation?
answerText:
Self-observation is for Vermonters who donât have symptoms of COVID-19. Follow these prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6Â feet apart.
Wear a mask.

Learn more about isolation, quarantine and self-observation.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What are the ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines?
answerText:
The ingredients in the COVID-19 vaccines are similar to what is found in other vaccines. They contain protein, and fats, salts and polysorbate. The mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) also have sugars and polyethylene glycol. They do not have any fetal tissue, pork products, eggs, gelatin, latex or preservatives in them.
Learn more about which vaccines are available in Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am an undocumented immigrant living in Vermont. Can I get the vaccine?
answerText:
Yes. You can get the vaccine when you are eligible based on age, health condition, job or setting.
When you make a vaccine appointment, you may be asked for certain information. The only answers that are needed to make a vaccine appointment are your name, date of birth, and address. This information is kept confidential since it is legally protected personal health information. If you live in Vermont but do not have an address or do not feel comfortable sharing this information, you can answer "UNKNOWN" in the street address field. You will still need to select âVTâ from the state dropdown field.
Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
Learn more about equal access to the vaccine for undocumented immigrants.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Iâm afraid of or triggered by needles. How can I get the vaccine?
answerText:
Many people are afraid of getting vaccines because they are often given with a needle. The physical reaction inside you is very real. There are ways to overcome these fears through conditioning and practice. This can help you get the COVID-19 vaccine and other lifesaving vaccines or medical treatments you may need during your life.
Here are a few things you can do:

Talk to your provider about what you can expect. Knowing what is coming can help.
Remember to breathe. This helps calm your body and mind.
Distract yourself from the procedure. Fix your focus on something else like a magazine or bring a support person to help.
Look away from the needle.
Think positive thoughts. Tell yourself that you are getting a shot for protection. Tell yourself you can do it. Then the more you do it, the easier it should be next time.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am a parent. What do I need to know, and how can I help keep my children safe from COVID-19?
answerText:
There are gathering restrictions in Vermont. Find out the current gathering restrictions.
If you are around other people, itâs safest to be outdoors. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19.
For outdoor recreation with people you donât live with, keep a physical distance of at least 6 feet and wear a mask. There are no other limitations to outdoor activities. Being active outside is good for our mental and physical health!
If you are a fully vaccinated parent or caregiver and are traveling with children, your children will need to quarantine when they return to Vermont. This is because children cannot get vaccinated yet. Learn more about traveling and quarantine.
Follow these general prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet apart.
Wear a mask (children over 2 who are able).

There will always be some risk of COVID-19 when we leave home, but it is possible to live your life and stay safer. Look for three things to help weigh the risk when making plans or going out:

6-Foot Spaces: Can I easily keep 6 feet from others?
Masks on Faces: Will people wear masks?
Uncrowded Places: Is there enough space for people to spread out?

Imagine these things as layers protecting us from getting and spreading COVID-19. The more layers we have, the lower the risk. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Children can also continue to take advantage of technology to play games or keep in touch with friends and family. These changes will continue to be difficult, but we are all doing our part to slow down this pandemic.
Learn more:

Resources for families with children
Coping with family stress during COVID-19
Face coverings for children
Frequently asked questions about school and child care
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am pregnant or breastfeeding. Should I get vaccinated?
answerText:
Pregnant people are at an increased risk for severe illness and for poor pregnancy outcomes if they get COVID-19. Any of the vaccines can be given to people who are pregnant or breastfeeding.
The three vaccines have not been studied in pregnant people. But medical and scientific experts believe they are unlikely to pose a risk to the pregnant person or fetus because the vaccines cannot copy themselves in the body or cause infection. TheÂ American College of Obstetrics and GynecologyÂ recommendsÂ that COVID-19 vaccines should not be withheld from people who are pregnant, want to become pregnant, or who are lactating.
There are no data on the safety of COVID-19 vaccines in people who are breastfeeding or the effects of the vaccines on milk production/excretion or on the breastfed baby. Since these vaccines do not reproduce inside your bodyâs cells, they are not thought to be a risk to the breastfed baby.
The CDC and other professional organizations recommend that you talk with your health care provider if you have any questions about the vaccines.
For more information, watch the video Sara Asks about the COVID-19 Vaccine, which is also available in other languages.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I have recovered from COVID-19. Can I donate my blood plasma to help other people suffering from COVID-19?
answerText:
If youâve fully recovered from COVID-19, the plasma in your blood may contain COVID-19 antibodies that can attack the virus. Plasma is being evaluated as a possible treatment for people who are currently sick with COVID-19.
The Red Cross is looking for people who have fully recovered from COVID-19 and would like to donate their plasma. If you are interested in donating your plasma, fill out the form on the Red Cross website.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I need to wait to get my vaccine if I am under quarantine or isolation?
answerText:
If you are under quarantine, you can leave quarantine to get your first or second dose of the vaccine. However, if you have symptoms of COVID-19, contact your health care provider. You will need to stay home and reschedule your appointment.
If you tested positive for COVID-19 and are still in your isolation period, you will need to wait to get your first or second dose until you are able to end your isolation.
There are enough appointment slots available for everyone who is eligible. You will be able to easily get another appointment. Find out how to reschedule your appointment.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do COVID-19 vaccines cause infertility?
answerText:
There is no evidence that fertility problems are a side effect of any vaccine, including COVID-19 vaccines.Â The American College of Obstetrics and GynecologyÂ recommends the vaccine for anyone who may want to get pregnant in the future.Â The vaccinesÂ do notÂ go intoÂ yourÂ DNA.
Learn more aboutÂ how mRNA vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna) work.
Learn more about how vector vaccines (Johnson & Johnson) work.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How many outbreaks are there in long-term care facilities?
answerText: There is a table showing active outbreaks in long-term care facilities. It is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays. You can also find a monthly report on COVID-19 in Vermont long-term care facilities. The report is updated on the first Tuesday of the month.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I get my second dose in Vermont if I got my first dose in another state?
answerText: Ideally, you should schedule your second dose at the same place you got your first dose. If thatâs not possible, you can call 855-722-7878 to schedule your second dose appointment. You will need to provide a Vermont address to register.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How is Vermont deciding when it is safe to reopen?
answerText:
Governor Scott released a phased reopening plan â Vermont Forward -- to help Vermonters and local businesses see the path for a phased return to unrestricted travel, business operations, and event gatherings. The plan was developed by the Department of Health, the Department of Public Safety, and the Agency of Commerce and Community Development and uses vaccination milestones to ensure a safe easing of personal restrictions and continued reopening of the state's economy.
Learn about the Vermont Forward Plan.
Read the latest Vermont COVID-19 modeling projections from the Vermont Department of Financial Regulation.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I have a high-risk health condition. How do I make an appointment for a vaccine?
answerText:
There are enough appointments for everyone who is eligible. Appointments are required. Clinics cannot accept walk-ins. Find out who is eligible.
Already have an account set up? Log in to your account to make an appointment.
Anyone who is unable to make their appointment online, needs help, or who wants to speak with someone in a language other than English can call 855-722-7878.
Create an Account
You will need to create an account in our online system first, and then log in to schedule your appointment. Even if youâre not currently eligible to get a vaccine, you can set up an account ahead of time.
You will need an email address to create an account, and can use the same address for more than one person. Learn more about what to do if you donât have an email address.
If you already have an account because you were tested for COVID-19 through a Health Department site, you need to use the same account information to schedule an appointment to get a vaccine. The online system will not allow you to create a new account if you use an email address that is already in the system.
Create an account.
Make a Vaccine Appointment
If you are eligible, find out what information you need and how to make a vaccine appointment.
You can also watch videos on how to:

make your vaccine appointment online
make an appointment if you are eligible by high-risk health condition or organization
add a dependent or spouse to your account

You can find a different appointment or adjust other appointment search criteria without losing your information. Click âCANCELâ to leave the âSchedule Appointmentâ screen, click on âSearch Eventâ in the menu to the left, change your search criteria, and then click âSchedule Appointmentâ to jump back to where you were.
Talk with your health care provider if you've had an immediate allergic reaction to any other vaccine, injectable therapy, or polysorbate, or if you have questions about whether getting the vaccine is right for you because of health conditions, allergies, or other vaccines you've received recently. Read the health screening questions asked before you get the vaccine.
For more information:

Tips for making a vaccine appointment
How to make a vaccine appointment for someone else
What to do if you have problems scheduling a vaccine appointment
What to expect at your vaccine appointment
Frequently asked questions about vaccine registration and appointments
Who will be eligible next to get the vaccine
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is the Health Department doing?
answerText:
People diagnosed with COVID-19 may have below-normal levels of oxygen in their blood before they feel short of breath. Finding low oxygen levels early helps people know that they need to seek medical care sooner. This could make the disease less severe.
The Health Department has a program that gives people who have tested positive for COVID-19 a free pulse oximeter to use at home. A pulse oximeter is a small device that clips onto your fingertip to measure your pulse and the oxygen levels in your body.
If you have tested positive for COVID-19, a Health Department staff member will contact you within 48 hours of receiving your lab result. They will ask questions about your symptoms and if you have a pulse oximeter at home. If you do not have one, you will receive one within one to two days, generally. You will then be asked to use it to monitor your oxygen levels throughout the day. The Health Department will continue to regularly contact you over the next several days to ask what your oxygen levels were and about any symptoms you may have.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Are children more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus? How can I help my children from getting sick?
answerText:
According to the CDC, while fewer children have been sick with COVID-19 compared to adults, children can be infected with the COVID-19 virus, can get sick from COVID-19, and can spread the virus to others. Children, like adults, who have COVID-19 but have no symptoms can still spread the virus to others.
Most children with COVID-19 have mild symptoms or have no symptoms at all. However, some children can get severely ill from COVID-19. They might require hospitalization, intensive care, or a ventilator to help them breathe. In rare cases, they might die. Babies under 1 year old and children with certain underlying conditions may be more likely to have severe illness from COVID-19. Learn more from the CDC about COVID-19 in children and teens.
A few children have developed Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C). Currently, information about MIS-C is limited, and the CDC is working to learn more.
You can teach your children the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19:

Stay home if you are sick.
Wash your hands often.
Keep your social circle small.
Stay at least 6 feet apart.
Wear a mask (children over 2 who are able).
Get the COVID-19 vaccine (when it becomes available to children).

Socializing for children is important for their development and wellbeing. There are ways children can socialize but still stay safe from getting or spreading COVID-19.
Find more resources for families with children and information from the CDC for children, teens and young adults.
You can find information about cases across age groups along with other COVID-19 data on the Vermont Dashboard. More detailed information is in the Weekly Data Summaries, which include more details on who has been impacted by COVID-19 in Vermont. You can find out more about testing trends, outbreaks, pre-existing conditions and symptoms of Vermonters with COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Are bars and restaurants open?
answerText:
Restaurants, bars and clubs are open under certain health and safety requirements.
Find more information about restaurants, catering, food service, social clubs and bars from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Why was the Johnson & Johnson vaccine paused?
answerText:
Vermont has resumed use of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine as of April 26. The FDA and CDC announced that they studied and confirmed that the Johnson & Johnson vaccine is recommended for people 18 years of age and older, and that the pause on its use since April 13 can be lifted.
The CDC announced the pause after reports of a small number of people developing a rare and severe type of blood clot called cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). This type of blood clot is found in the blood vessels that drain blood from the brain and is combined with low platelets.
There have been no reported cases of these side effects in Vermont.
The pause was necessary to give the CDCâs Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices time to review additional data about the reported side effects.
Vermontâs health care providers have been given information and guidance about the potential blood clotting symptoms and appropriate medical treatment. They will be given any updated guidance.
Although the side effects of concern are extremely rare, the FDA and CDC recommend that you should contact your health care provider right away if you develop severe headache, abdominal pain, leg pain or shortness of breath within three weeks of receiving the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
To register for an appointment or to change the one you already have, go online or call 855-722-7878. Certain participating pharmacy partners, including CVS and Walgreens, are making plans to also offer the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. You can contact those pharmacies directly to make an appointment or to reschedule.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I have to be a Vermont resident to get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answerText:
Yes. You will need to provide your address to make an appointment for the COVID-19 vaccine. However, if you live in another state, you can still get a vaccine in Vermont if:

You work in one of these occupations or settings in Vermont: health care personnel, child care worker, work in a school, or work in the public safety system.
You moved to Vermont within the last 6 months with the intention of becoming a resident.
You attend a college, university or other educational institution in Vermont (including boarding school).
You live in Vermont for part of the year.

If you are a resident of another state and have a primary care provider in Vermont, you are not eligible to get a vaccine in Vermont. This is because primary care providers do not have vaccine to give right now. You will need to get the vaccine in your home state.
Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Is it possible to get COVID-19 even if Iâm fully vaccinated?
answerText:
Yes. COVID-19 vaccines are very effective at preventing serious disease, including hospitalization and death. But no vaccine is 100% effective. That means some people who are vaccinated may become infected with COVID-19. This is called a âvaccine breakthrough.â This happens with any vaccine including measles, mumps, flu and others.
As more people are vaccinated, it is likely that the number of people who get sick with COVID-19 even after getting vaccinated will increase, especially if the amount of COVID-19 virus in our communities remains high. This growing number may sound concerning, but this is expected. Fortunately, the percentage of people who get COVID-19 after being vaccinated should stay low. Among those who get COVID-19 after being vaccinated, few will get very sick.
Community Immunity
Vaccine protection is more than one person being vaccinated. The more virus going around in the community, the higher your chances of coming into close contact with someone who is sick with COVID-19. When enough people in a community are protected against a contagious disease, it's very hard for it to spread. It is this community immunity that helps protect us all from getting sick. This is why â until we reach community immunity and the amount of virus in our community goes down â our prevention steps are so important.
Variants
Scientific studies show that some vaccines may not work as well on some of the variants. Studies with people in real world conditions are ongoing. Variants are circulating in Vermont and the numbers of people getting sick with COVID-19 is rising. Vermontâs numbers are too small to make any conclusions about the role of variants and the infections among fully vaccinated people that we are seeing. The Health Department is working to increase our ability to sequence more samples and select certain samples, like those among fully vaccinated people to look at more closely.
Learn more from the CDC about:

What you should know about the possibility of COVID-19 illness after vaccination
Vaccine breakthrough cases
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do college students need to know?
answerText:
Vaccination
All college students can get vaccinated now. Make a vaccine appointment.
Getting Tested Due to Travel
If you are a college student coming home to Vermont and are not vaccinated, you must get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont. Day 0 is the day you arrive back in Vermont. Find free and fast testing throughout Vermont.
If you are an out-of-state college student coming to Vermont and are not vaccinated, you must get tested within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.
In both cases above, the test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).
Parents or other visitors who are not vaccinated will need to get tested within 3 days before arriving in Vermont. Learn more about the travel rules for visitors to Vermont. Find answers to frequently asked questions about travel.
If you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months (and donât have new symptoms), you do not need to get tested.
General Guidance and Other Resources
Colleges and universities must follow the Mandatory Guidance for College and University Campus Learning. Please contact your college or university directly for information about arriving on campus, testing and health guidance.
Find out what happens at the Health Department when someone tests positive for COVID-19.
Find tips for how to enjoy safer sex and reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19 and more resources for college students.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I have a choice of which vaccine I get? Which vaccine should I get?
answerText:
If you are making an appointment through the Health Department system, you will see the name of the vaccine listed after the âeventâ description. However, there is no way to search for an appointment based on which vaccine is available. Currently, most clinics are offering the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines (two-dose), and some are offering the Johnson & Johnson (single dose) vaccine. Learn about why the Johnson & Johnson vaccine was briefly paused.
Please note that only sites with the Pfizer vaccine will show up for people age 16 and 17 since that is the only vaccine that has been authorized for people age 16 and older. You may need to look at neighboring counties if nothing comes up in your county.
For the two-dose vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna), you should get the same vaccine for both your first and second dose. You will also be given a card with the name of the vaccine you received when you get your first shot. If you have a smartphone, you may want to take a picture of the card in case you misplace it.
Find out how to make your second dose appointment.
All three vaccines (Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson) are safe and similarly effective at preventing severe illness and death. This standard is what is most commonly used to assess other vaccines like the flu shot. We cannot directly compare the effectiveness of the three vaccines because they were not studied against each other at the same time. Each clinical trial had different study protocols, timing and location. For example, variants werenât widely circulating when the earlier vaccines were being tested.
The vaccines available have similar side effects. Side effects are a normal way that your body builds immunity to COVID-19.
Learn more about the vaccines available in Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Why canât children and adolescents get the COVID-19 vaccine?
answerText:
Childrenâs immune systems are different at different ages. They are also different from adults.
In early April, Pfizer-BioNTech asked the FDA to expand use of its COVID-19 vaccine to adolescents ages 12 to 15. If approved, we may be able to start vaccinating this age group in May or June. We will provide more details when we have them.
Moderna and Johnson & Johnson are each running clinical vaccine trials with adolescents aged 12 to 17. Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna have clinical trials of their vaccines for younger children going on now.
If the trials are successful, there will be the usual review processes before the vaccines can be approved for emergency use and then produced for distribution. This process can take a while, especially for very young ages, which are usually tested last.

The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is authorized for people 16 years and older.
The Moderna vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.
The Johnson & Johnson (Janssen) vaccine is authorized for people 18 years and older.

Because children under 16 cannot get vaccinated at this time, they will need to get tested when they travel and are not considered part of a fully vaccinated household. Learn more about traveling out of state and gathering restrictions.
Find out what children age 16 and 17 need to do to get vaccinated.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Who will be eligible next?
answerText:
All Vermont residents age 16 and older are eligible to be vaccinated. Some residents of another state are also eligible.
Make an appointment to get the COVID-19 vaccine.
You can also find specific clinic locations for certain groups:

People who are homebound
Clinic options for Black, Indigenous and people of color (BIPOC)
Clinic options for English language learners and people in immigrant/refugee communities

Learn about how we are working toward equity.
The goal is to have Vermonters fully vaccinated by July. The length of the entire process will vary, but you can expect it to take about 2 months from when you sign up to when you are considered fully vaccinated. This includes the time between when you make your appointment, the time of getting your first and final dose, and the 14 days after your final dose for the vaccine to be most effective.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How do I protect my vaccine card? Can I get a new one if I lose it?
answerText:
Once you get your vaccine card, put it in a safe place so you donât lose it. You can keep it in your wallet or store it with other important documents. You can also take a picture of it with your smartphone, if you have one. You may need to show your card when you travel, so be sure to carry it with you and be prepared to show it when asked.
If your vaccine requires a second dose, you should have scheduled your second dose at the clinic where you received your first dose. We recommend bringing your vaccine card to your second dose appointment, but it is not required.
You may want to protect your card. If you choose to get your vaccine card laminated, please note that the ink used to write in your dose could run when heat is applied. Also, if booster shots are needed, they wonât be able to be recorded if the card is laminated.
If you lost your vaccine card, the Vermont Immunization Registry has your vaccination record. You can request a record of your vaccine from the Immunization Registry directly or through your health care provider. To request it directly through the Immunization Registry, email vaxrecordrequest@vermont.gov or call 888-688-4667, option 3. You can get a copy of your record as an encrypted email or through the mail. On weekdays, you can expect an email within an hour or two. Mail will take about one week.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What should businesses and non-profits do?
answerText:
As part of Vermont's phased reopening plan, businesses are transitioning from sector-specific guidance to universal guidance. The transition will happen in two phases depending on which sector your business belongs to. Find out more about business operations and universal guidance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
More resources:

Health guidance and resources for businesses
What to do if an employee tests positive for COVID-19
What to do if a guest or visitor at your establishment tests positive for COVID-19
What to do if you operate a critical infrastructure business and your essential workers are close contacts
Checklist for Employers: COVID-19 in the Workplace
COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses
COVID-19 Recovery Resource Center for Businesses from the ACCD
Best Practices for Retail Food Stores, Restaurants, and Food Pick-Up/Delivery Services During the COVID-19 Pandemic from the Food and Drug Administration

The Health Department and Agency of Agriculture do not recommend the use of fogging, fumigation, âelectrostatic or wide-area spraying on hard surfaces to control the spread of COVID-19. These methods, while they can be effective, âare unnecessary and do not clean contaminated surfaces. They also may result in chemical exposures to workers and the public. Additionally, the Environmental Protection Agency does not recommend using these methods to apply disinfectants unless the label specifically states it is appropriate to do so.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: If I go on vacation, do I need to quarantine before I return to work?
answerText:
If you travel out of Vermont for vacation and are not vaccinated, you will need to get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont. Day 0 is the day you arrive back in Vermont. If you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months (and donât have new symptoms), you do not need to get tested when you return to Vermont.
Find out more about the travel rules for Vermonters traveling out of state.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do owners of lodging facilities need to do?
answerText:
As part of Vermont's phased reopening plan, businesses are transitioning from sector-specific guidance to universal guidance. Effective April 9, 2021, lodging, campgrounds and other accommodations need to follow universal guidance. Find out more about universal guidance from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development (ACCD).
Out-of-state guests who are staying at a lodging, camping or short-term rental property in Vermont must self-certify that they meet certain conditions.
Read the COVID-19 Guidance for Food and Lodging Businesses and find more resources for food and lodging businesses from the Health Department.
Find out what to do if a guest or visitor at your establishment tests positive for COVID-19 from the Health Department.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do parents need to know about school and child care?
answerText:
Children need structure, relationships with their peers, teachers, and other adults for their academic, social, and emotional development. Although remote learning is an important tool during the pandemic, it can lead to even greater gaps in equity. Public health and education experts considered all these factors when writing Vermontâs guidance to open schools, which focuses on the safety of teachers, staff, and students.
Vermont has seen cases and outbreaks in schools and child care, but by following health guidance, we are all working together to keep the virus out of schools as much as possible and prevent it from spreading through physical distancing, wearing masks, hand hygiene, and contact tracing.
Helpful resources for parents:

What parents can expect for pre-K through 12th grade
Safety and health guidance for Vermont schools from the Agency of Education
School-based sports program guidance from the Agency of Education
Music education guidance from the Agency of Education
Child care and out-of-school-time care guidance
Overnight summer camp operations guidance
Returning to school following illness
Returning to child care or an out of school care program following illness
What if there is a case of COVID-19 in school?
COVID-19 cases in K-12 learning communities while infectious
Strategies and resources for educators and families from the Agency of Education
Vermont PBS distance learning
More information for families with children
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am fully vaccinated. Do I need to follow any travel rules if I am traveling to or returning to Vermont?
answerText:
If it has been 14 days since you got your final vaccine dose, you do not need to get tested when you travel to or return to Vermont. Be sure to carry your COVID-19 vaccine card with you and be prepared to show it when asked.
Anyone who is not vaccinated and travels with you will need to follow the travel rules (including children) when they travel to or return to Vermont. For example, if you are a fully vaccinated parent or caregiver and are traveling with children, your children will need to get tested before they travel to or after they return to Vermont. Learn about Vermonters hosting visitors in their homes.
Masks are required in public spaces in Vermont. There are also gathering restrictions.
If you are a health care worker, check with your employer about any additional requirements.
We recommend that everyone, including people who got the COVID-19 vaccine, continue to follow prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19. Learn more about how to keep staying safe.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Are there any travel rules if I traveled out of state and am returning to Vermont?
answerText:
Yes. As part of Vermont's phased reopening plan, there is new travel guidance. Except for international travel, travel no longer requires quarantine.
CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19.
Unvaccinated Vermonters (including children) who have traveled outside the state must be tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont. Day 0 is the day you arrive back in Vermont.

The test you get must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).
Find free and fast testing near you.
You do not need to quarantine while you wait for a result. But if you have any symptoms, stay home and away from other people.
Quarantining does not exempt you from the testing requirement. You may choose to quarantine, but you are still required to get a test when you return to Vermont.

Fully vaccinated Vermonters do not need to get tested. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot.
People who have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months do not need to test unless they develop new symptoms. If it has been more than 3 months since you recovered from COVID-19, you will need to get tested.
There are no additional restrictions for people taking public transportation. However, The CDC requires people to wear masks when using public transportation.
Rules for Vermonters who have traveled to other countries are different. Learn more about international travel.
Find out more about what to do when you return to Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am under a 14-day quarantine. Can I have the option to be tested and end my quarantine period?
answerText:
If you are currently under quarantine and have had no symptoms of COVID-19 during the first seven days of quarantine, you have the option to be tested and end your quarantine early. The test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).
You can end your quarantine period before 14 days only if:

You have not had symptoms during your quarantine period;
You are tested on day 7 or later;
You remain in quarantine until the result comes back;
You receive a negative test result and are still not having symptoms; and
You continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days.

If you develop symptoms at any point during your quarantine, contact your health care provider and the Health Department right away.
There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. Find out where to get tested.
If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
Studies have found most people will develop symptoms by day 7. This is why there is the option for people to be tested on day 7 or after in their quarantine and, if the test is negative, to end quarantine.
Residents and staff of group living facilities (for example long-term care facilities or corrections facilities) and new admissions to nursing homes, assisted living residences, and residential care homes must complete the full 14-day quarantine.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I am hosting out-of-state visitors in my home. Do I need to quarantine?
answerText:
Yes, but there are some restrictions. Under the current gathering guidelines, hosting visitors is considered a social gathering. Both you and your guests must follow Vermontâs gathering restrictions.
Find moreÂ travel informationÂ and answers toÂ frequently asked questions about travel.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I stay overnight at any lodging, camping or short-term rental property in Vermont?
answerText:
Yes. You can stay overnight at any lodging establishment, short-term rental (for example, VRBO, Homeaway, Airbnb, etc.), public or private campground, RV park, or seasonal resort or marina.
When you arrive at the lodging site, you and anyone traveling with you must self-certify that you meet one of these conditions:

Have had a negative test result within 3 days before arriving in Vermont. The test must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as rapid test) or
Are authorized to work in Vermont or
Are fully vaccinated or
Have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months and do not currently have any symptoms.

And you must also meet both of these conditions:

Not had close contact with someone with COVID-19 in the past 14 days and
Not had COVID-19-like symptoms in the past 24 hours.

You are strongly encouraged to sign up with Sara Alert to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
Find more travel information for visitors to Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I need to quarantine if I live with someone or had close contact with someone who is under quarantine?
answerText:
Yes. You will need to quarantine if you are a close contact or live with someone who tests positive for COVID-19 (unless you are fully vaccinated or recently had COVID-19). If you are identified as a close contact, you will be contacted. This is known as contact tracing. The notification will come from the Health Department or a place you went to recently (for example, your employer, your childâs school, or your health care provider might contact you). They will give you guidance to stay home and away from others for a certain amount of time.
Learn more about what to expect from contact tracing.
Find tips about quarantining when you share a home.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What is quarantine?
answerText:
Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from other people. This helps to prevent the spread of COVID-19 before a person knows they are sick, or if they are infected with the virus and donât have symptoms.
Quarantine is for people who were in close contact with someone with COVID-19 (unless you are fully vaccinated or recently had COVID-19). Day 1 of your quarantine starts the day after you were last in contact with them.
Quarantine means you need to stay home and away from other people for 14 days. This means you canât do any activities outside of your home, like going to school, work, or out to do errands. You should separate yourself from others and check yourself for symptoms. Call your health care provider if you start to feel sick. If you do not have a health care provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermontâs free & referral clinics.
You are allowed to go outside for a walk or a bike ride while you are in quarantine only if:

you do not have any symptoms,
you are alone,
you wear a mask at all times,
you are in an uncrowded place, and
you can stay at least 6 feet from other people at all times.

For example, you can go for a walk or bike ride in your neighborhood. You should not go for a walk or bike ride on a bike path, on busy hiking or biking trails, or in a downtown area.
You can end quarantine early if you get tested on or after day 7 of your quarantine and get a negative test result. You must not have had any symptoms of COVID-19, and must continue to monitor yourself for symptoms for the full 14 days. Find out more about the option to end your quarantine early.
Find out if you need to quarantine if:

You are a close contact of someone with COVID-19.
You had close contact with someone who is under quarantine.
You live with or had close contact with someone who tested positive.
You live with someone who is waiting for their test results.
You take care of someone who is in isolation and canât avoid close contact with them.
You take care of someone who is in quarantine and canât avoid close contact with them.

Learn more:

What is isolation, quarantine and self-observation?
What to do if you are a close contact of someone with COVID-19
Timeline for close contacts of people with COVID-19
Tips about quarantining when you share a home
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I need to bring my negative test result or my vaccine card with me when I travel to Vermont?
answerText:
Yes. You should bring a copy of your negative test result or your vaccine card with you and be prepared to show it when asked.
If you are staying at a lodging, camping or short-term rental property in Vermont, you must also self-certify that you meet certain conditions.
Find more travel information for visitors to Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I need to get tested if I make a short trip (day trip)?
answerText:
If you are traveling for an essential purpose, you may make day trips to another state (or to Vermont if you live in another state) without getting tested. This includes travel for personal safety, health care, care, care of others, food and beverage, medicine, work, parental shared custody, and for students who commute daily to attend preK-12 school or college or a school-sponsored activity.
The exemption to testing only applies to the person under essential travel rules. It does not apply to anyone else who travels with you. For example, you travel for work and your child comes with you. Your child will need to get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont, but you wonât need to.
If you live within 5 miles of the Vermont border, you may make day trips without getting tested if you travel 5 miles into a neighboring state or into Vermont for an essential purpose or for certain activities. This includes going to worship, going to a gym, getting a haircut, and participating in place-based outdoor recreation. Find out more about travel to and from border towns.
If you are traveling for leisure and go on a day trip, you must get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont. If you live in another state, you must get tested within 3 days before traveling to Vermont. The CDC requires people to wear masks when using public transportation. If you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months (and donât have new symptoms), you do not need to get tested before you visit or return to Vermont.
Find more travel information for Vermonters traveling out of state and visitors to Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I want to travel to Vermont from a foreign country. Is that allowed?
answerText:
If you are planning on traveling internationally, check the currentÂ list of Travel Advisories by countryÂ from the U.S. Department of State, and visitÂ travel.state.govÂ for detailed information on safe international travel. See CDC guidance on testing and international travel.
Visit theÂ CDCâs travel pageÂ forÂ travel recommendations by countryÂ and see theÂ FAQs for Travelers.
International travelers can get tested in Vermont for free. Learn more about getting tested for COVID-19.
Follow the CDCâsÂ âafter international travelâ guidanceÂ when you enter the U.S.
Find out about travel from Canada.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I traveled internationally or by cruise ship. What do I need to do when I return to Vermont?
answerText:
If you are planning on traveling internationally, check the current list of Travel Advisories by country from the U.S. Department of State, and visit travel.state.gov for detailed information on safe international travel. See CDC guidance on testing and international travel.
Visit the CDCâs travel page for travel recommendations by country and see the FAQs for Travelers.
The CDC recommends no one travel on cruise ships, including river cruises, worldwide, especially people with an increased risk of serious illness. Thatâs because the risk of COVID-19 on cruise ships is high. Learn more about cruise ships and river cruise voyages.
You must follow travel restrictions and quarantine requirements for the countries you plan to visit.
Follow the CDCâsÂ âafter international travelâ guidanceÂ when you enter the U.S.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I travel to or from Canada?
answerText:
Check CDCâs travel notices for Canada and read Canadaâs entry restrictions for current information about travel to or from Canada.
Follow the CDCâsÂ âafter international travelâ guidanceÂ when you enter the U.S.
International travelers can get tested in Vermont for free. Learn more about getting tested for COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: If I travel, do I need to quarantine before getting tested or while Iâm waiting for my test results?
answerText:
No. There is no quarantine required due to travel.
For example, if you are an unvaccinated Vermonter (including children)Â returning from travel outside of the state, you do not need to quarantine when you come back to Vermont or while you are waiting for your test results. You only need to get a test within 3 days of returning to Vermont.
Or, if you are an unvaccinated visitor to Vermont (including children), you do not need to quarantine while you are waiting for your test results before you come to Vermont. You only need to get a test within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.
You may choose to quarantine, but quarantine does not exempt you from the testing requirement. You are still required to get a negative test before coming to Vermont or get tested when you return to Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I have parental shared custody. Can my child and I travel without quarantining?
answerText:
Travel for parental shared custody is considered essential travel. This means that you and your child do not need to get tested if:

You are returning to Vermont after visiting your child out of state.
Your child lives out of state and is visiting you in Vermont.
You live out of state and your child is returning to Vermont after visiting you.

You can travel by personal vehicle, plane, train, bus or other means of transportation. We encourage you to choose the form of travel with the lowest risk when you can. Your personal vehicle would have the lowest risk.
However, if you and your child travel out of Vermont for leisure for a non-essential purpose, you and your child must get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont. This includes day trips. The CDC requires people to wear masks when using public transportation. If you are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months (and donât have new symptoms), you do not need to get tested when you return to Vermont, but your child will.
Children in shared custody that are in isolation because they have tested positive for COVD-19, or are in quarantine because they were identified as a close contact of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19, may isolate or quarantine in either household. It does not affect the shared custody schedule. However, this means that members of the household where the child is staying may need to quarantine. If the child is in isolation, household members will be required to quarantine. If the child is in quarantine, household members would not need to also quarantine, unless the child tests positive for COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: I had COVID-19 or received a positive antibody test. Does that mean I am exempt from the travel rules?
answerText:
If you had COVID-19 within the last 3 months and have recovered, you do not need to test unless you develop new symptoms. If you had COVID-19 and itâs been more than 3 months since you recovered, you must get tested when you travel to or return to Vermont under the current travel rules.
If you received a positive antibody test, you must get tested when you travel to or return to Vermont under the current travel rules. Getting a positive antibody test, that does not mean you have âproof of immunityâ from COVID-19.
Everyone must follow the current social gathering restrictions.
Currently, we recommend that everyone, including people who had COVID-19 or received a positive antibody test, continue to follow the prevention steps to keep from getting or spreading COVID-19.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Are there any travel rules for people visiting Vermont, including people who own second or seasonal homes?
answerText:
Yes. As part of Vermont's phased reopening plan, there is new travel guidance. Except for international travel, travel no longer requires quarantine.
CDC recommends delaying travel until you are fully vaccinated, because travel increases your chance of getting and spreading COVID-19.
Unvaccinated people (including children) must have a COVID-19 test within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.

The test you get must be for a current infection (like a PCR test), except it cannot be an antigen test (also known as a rapid test).
If the test is positive, do not come to Vermont.
Please bring proof of your negative test result with you.
Quarantining does not exempt you from the testing requirement. You may choose to quarantine, but you are still required to get a negative test before coming to Vermont.

Fully vaccinated people do not need to get tested. You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot.
People who have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 3 months do not need to test unless they develop new symptoms. If it has been more than 3 months since you recovered from COVID-19, you will need to get tested.
There are no additional restrictions for people taking public transportation. However, The CDC requires people to wear masks when using public transportation.
Rules for visitors from other countries are different. Learn more about international travel.
Masks are required in public spaces in Vermont. There are also gathering restrictions.
Learn about overnight stays in lodging, camping or short-term rental properties.
We strongly encourage you to sign up with Sara Alert once you arrive in Vermont to get two weeks of daily symptom check reminders.
Find more travel information for visitors to Vermont.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I get COVID-19 from swimming in a lake or river?
answerText:
There is no evidence that the virus can spread to people through the water in pools, hot tubs or water playgrounds. Proper operation and disinfection of the water (for example, with chlorine and bromine) should kill the virus.
There is also no evidence that the COVID-19 virus spreads to people through the water in lakes, oceans, rivers or other natural bodies of water.
The virus has been found in untreated wastewater, which means it could possibly enter lakes or rivers when untreated wastewater is discharged into waterways after rainstorms or for other reasons. According to the CDC, it is currently thought that the risk of getting COVID-19 from properly designed and maintained sewerage systems is low because the wastewater treatment process removes and degrades many viruses and bacteria. There has been no information to date that anyone has become sick with COVID-19 because they came in contact with wastewater.
The Health Department recommends that towns do routine weekly E. coli testing and after large rainstorms during the swim season. These tests are a good indication of the water quality, meaning that if the E. coli levels are low, then COVID-19 virus levels are also expected to be low.
The best practices for staying healthy while swimming are to obey signage at beaches, do not swim during and following large rainstorms, and do not swallow the water.
Learn more about healthy swimming and find more frequently asked questions about pools, hot tubs and water playgrounds from the CDC.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: What do I need to know about COVID-19 testing? Where can I get tested?
answerText:
There are a variety of testing options available to you: your health care provider, pharmacies and Health Department testing sites. You can make an appointment or just walk in. Testing is free to all, and many sites now let you take your own sample using a short swab in your nose.
Find out where to get tested.
Anyone can get tested at a Health Department testing site if they do not have symptoms. This includes children 12 months or older, people who work in Vermont, visitors to Vermont and international travelers. Infants under 12 months can get tested at their health care providerâs office. Anyone under 18 should be accompanied by a parent or guardian or bring a signed parental consent form.
If you have symptoms of COVID-19, do not go to a testing site. Talk to your health care provider about getting tested.
If you or your child don't have a provider, call 2-1-1 to be connected to care, or contact the nearest federally qualified health center or one of Vermont's free & referral clinics. If you are visiting Vermont or are an international traveler, you will need to contact your primary care provider or call Vermont 2-1-1 if you do not have a provider.
The Health Department recommends testing as soon as possible when:

You have symptoms of COVID-19 (call your health care provider first).
You are referred by your health care provider.
You are not fully vaccinated and a person in your workplace or household, or a person you attended an event with, tests positive for COVID-19.
You are not fully vaccinated and you gather with multiple households at a time or attend an event. You should get tested as soon as 2 days after the gathering, and again 7 days after the gathering. Learn more about why you should get tested.

You are fully vaccinated 14 days after your final shot. Until you are fully vaccinated, you should follow the same guidance as unvaccinated people.
Unvaccinated visitors to Vermont (including children)Â must get tested within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.
Unvaccinated Vermonters (including children)Â must get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont. Day 0 is the day you arrive back in Vermont.
You may come to a Health Department testing site to get tested more than once if you have reason to be concerned about infection.
If you need a ride to the testing site, schedule your appointment first, and then call 833-387-7200 at least two days before the appointment.
Find out:

Where to get tested and how to schedule an appointment
What to expect at a Health Department testing site â including answers to more questions about testing
What to do while youâre waiting for test results and how to get your test results
When you will get your test results
What the different types of tests are
How many Vermonters have been tested â this information is updated daily.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Iâm 16 or 17. What do I need to know about getting my vaccine?
answerText:
If you are making an appointment through the Health Department website, youâll need to create an account. Either you can create your own account, or your parent or guardian can add you as a dependent on their account.
When you make your appointment, you will only see appointments for the Pfizer vaccine since that is the only vaccine that is authorized for people age 16 and 17. Sometimes you may need to look at neighboring counties if nothing comes up in your county.
Your parent or guardian will need to review the consent forms and check the box giving their consent for you to get the vaccine. Since the consent is built into the registration process, your parent or guardian will not need to go with you to your appointment.
If you are making an appointment directly through Walgreens, your parent or guardian will need to go with you to your appointment and give their consent.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: If I have symptoms after getting the vaccine, can I go to work if I donât pass the health screening?
answerText: No. There are some signs and symptoms that could be related to getting the COVID-19 vaccine or being infected with the COVID-19 virus or another virus (like the flu). These include fever, chills, fatigue and muscle aches. If you have these symptoms, whether you got the COVID-19 vaccine or not, you should not go to work and you should call your health care provider. If your health care provider determines that your symptoms are associated with the COVID-19 vaccine, then you can return to work if you feel well enough to do so.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How many cases of COVID-19 are in the U.S.?
answerText: You can find a school-by-school listing of COVID-19 cases in Vermont K-12 learning communities while infectious. The list is updated on Tuesdays and Fridays with data through the previous Sunday and Wednesday, respectively.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: When do I need to get my second shot?
answerText:
The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are two shots, given 21 or 28 days apart. Both of them are over 94% effective with two doses.

Doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine are given about 21 days apart.
Doses of the Moderna vaccine are given about 28 days apart.

For the vaccine to be the most effective and help prevent you from getting COVID-19, itâs best to get your second shot as close to the recommended schedule as possible. It is okay to get your shot 4 days before the recommended schedule. But if you miss your second dose, get it as soon as you can. However, if you are not able to get it close to the recommended schedule, it is okay to get it up to 42 days after your first dose. There is limited data on how effective the vaccine is, if the second dose is given after 42 days. Learn more about why it is important to get two doses of the vaccine.
Once you get your vaccine card, put it in a safe place so you donât lose it. You can keep it in your wallet or store it with other important documents. You can also take a picture of it with your smartphone, if you have one. You may need to show your card when you travel, so be sure to carry it with you and be prepared to show it when asked.
We recommend bringing your vaccine card to your second dose appointment, but it is not required. We also recommend getting your second dose at the same place you got your first dose. This way you can be sure that you get the same vaccine.
Find out:

How to schedule your second dose appointment
How to reschedule or cancel your second dose appointment
How to schedule a second dose appointment if you got your first dose in another state
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: How can I report a business or person who is not complying with the Governor's executive orders?
answerText:
Enforcement of the Governorâs executive orders is mainly done through education and voluntary compliance.

For concerns about businesses, lodging establishments, short-term rental properties, nonprofits or other entities that are not complying with the Governorâs orders, call your local law enforcement agency, or file a report by contacting the Vermont Department of Health at 802-863-7240 (toll-free 833-722-0860) or AHS.VDHPublicCommunication@vermont.gov.
For concerns or complaints about restaurants, use the Health Departmentâs online sanitation complaint form, email FoodLodging@vermont.gov, or call 802-863-7221.
For employees to report alleged safety or health hazards, use the Vermont Occupational Safety and Health Administrationâs (VOSHA) confidential online safety complaint form.
For complaints about people who are not quarantining as required, call your local law enforcement agency. Do not dial 911. Only use their non-emergency number when calling in a report.

Learn more about how the executive orders are enforced.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Where can I get vaccinated?
answerText:
There are many vaccination sites across the state. Vaccines are available at regional clinics offered by the state and through our partner pharmacies. More sites will become available as we get more vaccine from the federal government.
You can make an appointment for a clinic or pharmacy near you through the Health Department website. This includes clinics run by the Health Department, the National Guard, health care partners, Costco, Hannaford, Price Chopper, Rite Aid, Shaws and Walmart (please do not call the stores directly). Make an appointment.
You can find a map of the areas where vaccination sites are, not actual locations. When you schedule your appointment, you will get the address of the vaccination site you chose. Find the map of vaccination sites.
If you would like to make an appointment for a Kinney Drugs, CVS, Walgreens or Northfield Pharmacy near you, you can make an appointment directly through their websites. Make an appointment with Kinney Drugs, CVS, Walgreens or Northfield Pharmacy.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can we still have our wedding ceremony?
answerText:
You can get a marriage license from Vermont town offices. Check with the town office on how to get your license since they may be operating remotely or offering curbside service. Find up-to-date information on wedding ceremonies, including the number of people that are allowed, from the Agency of Commerce and Community Development.
Unvaccinated visitors to Vermont (including children)Â must get tested within 3 days before arriving in Vermont.
Masks are required in public spaces in Vermont. There are also gathering restrictions.
Have your ceremony outdoors whenever possible. Because of the nature of how the virus spreads and how it survives, being indoors increases your risk of spreading or getting COVID-19. Find more tips on preventing COVID-19.
Find more travel information and answers to frequently asked questions about travel.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Can I move to Vermont or come to Vermont to view an apartment or home?
answerText:
Yes, but if you are not vaccinated, you will need to get tested within 3 days before arriving in Vermont. Learn more about the travel rules for visitors to Vermont. People moving to Vermont for work must also follow the travel rules.
Moving services and real estate and related services (such as title searches, appraisals, and home inspections) are operating under universal guidance. You are required to wear a mask and stay at least 6 feet from people you donât live with.
More housing information is available at the Agency of Commerce and Community Development's (ACCDâs) COVID-19 Resource Recovery Center.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Are sports and outdoor activities allowed?
answerText:
Yes. Even though there are restrictions on social gatherings, you can do outdoor recreation and fitness activities with anyone. This includes biking, hiking, walking, running, hunting and fishing, and other low-contact outdoor activities. However, you must stay at least 6 feet away from people you donât live with and wear a mask at all times. Try not to gather at trailheads, access areas or other outdoor facilities before or after the activity.
Businesses, facilities and organizations that support or offer outdoor recreation and outdoor fitness activities are following universal guidance.
Sports and organized sports (including youth leagues, adult leagues, practices, games and tournaments) are following specialized guidance. For school sports, read the school-based sports program guidance.
Find out more about outdoor recreation and COVID-19 from the Vermont Department of Forests, Parks and Recreation and the Vermont Fish and Wildlife Department.
title: Vermont | Covid-19 FAQ

questionText: Do I need to quarantine if I'm traveling for an essential purpose (like work in a neighboring state or parental shared custody)?
answerText:
If you are traveling for essential purposes, you do not need to get tested before traveling to Vermont or after returning to Vermont. Essential travel includes travel for:

personal safety
health care
care of others
food, beverage or medicine
work
parental shared custody
students who commute daily to attend preK-12 school or college or a school-sponsored activity

Travel for funeral services is not considered essential. You will need to follow all travel guidance before you come to Vermont or when you return to Vermont.
The exemption to testing only applies to the person under essential travel rules. It does not apply to anyone else who travels with you. For example, you travel for work and your child comes with you. Your child will need to get tested within 3 days of returning to Vermont, but you wonât need to.
If you live within 5 miles of the Vermont border, you may make day trips without getting tested if you travel 5 miles into a neighboring state or into Vermont for an essential purpose or for certain activities.
